[[File:Peachtree-Pine shelter.jpg|thumb| The [[Peachtree-Pine shelter]] in [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]]]] '''Homeless shelters''' are a type of homeless service agency which provide temporary residence for [[homelessness|homeless]] individuals and families. Shelters exist to provide residents with safety and protection from exposure to the weather while simultaneously reducing the [[environmental impact]] on the community. They are similar to, but distinguishable from, various types of [[emergency shelter]]s, which are typically operated for specific circumstances and populations—fleeing natural disasters or abusive social circumstances. Extreme weather conditions create problems similar to [[disaster management]] scenarios, and are handled with [[warming center]]s, which typically operate for short durations during adverse weather.
== Homeless population == [[File:The Good Shepherd, a Salvation Army homeless shelter on Jarvis Street, 2013 10 21.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The Good Shepherd, a Salvation Army homeless shelter in Toronto.]] ===Health issues=== Hundreds of homeless individuals die each year from diseases, untreated medical conditions, lack of nutrition, starvation, and freezing to death. In a mild-wintered San Francisco in 1998, homeless people were purportedly 58% more likely to perish than the general population. In [[New Orleans]], approximately 10,000 homeless were unaccounted for after [[Hurricane Katrina]] in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bwh&AN=18673816&site=ehost-live|title = N.O. Loses 10,000 Homeless People to Uncertain Fates|last = Webster|first = Richard A.|date = 10 October 2005|work = New Orleans CityBusiness|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = Regional Business News - EBSCO}}</ref> Residents of homeless shelters may also be exposed to [[Bed bug (insect)|bed bug]]s which have been growing more prevalent in countries such as the United States, Canada and in Europe.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=16608554&site=ehost-live|title = Bed Bug Infestations in an Urban Environment|last = Hwang|first = Stephen W.|date = April 2005|journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases|doi = 10.3201/eid1104.041126|pmid = 15829190|access-date = 23 July 2015|last2 = Svoboda|first2 = Tomislav J.|issue = 4|volume = 11|subscription = yes|pages = 533–538|last3 = De Jong|first3 = Lain J.|last4 = Kabasele|first4 = Karl J.|last5 = Gogosis|first5 = Evie|pmc=3320350}}</ref> Some residents of shelters have reported sleeping in roach-infested spaces at various shelters.<ref>{{Cite book|title = A Case Study of the Social and Education Experiences of Homeless Children|last = Shankar-Brown|first = Rajni|publisher = University of North Carolina at Charlotte|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Charlotte, North Carolina|pages = 240|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JT1pEFkCFKIC&lpg=PA240&dq=%22homeless%20shelters%22&pg=PA239#v=onepage&q=%22homeless%20shelters%22&f=false}}</ref>
In [[Washington, D.C.]], statistics indicate that 63% of homeless people suffer from a lack of access to regular bathing. Another estimated 58% within the same city are unable to obtain sufficient levels of sleep. Areas such as showers and bathrooms in shelters often have restricted access with limited hours.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/4/15/more-pads-for-homeless-women-help.html|title = More Pads for Homeless Women On Their Periods|last = De Bode|first = Lisa|date = 15 April 2015|work = Aljazeera America|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = }}</ref> Homeless individuals also have great trouble finding storage locations for their belongings. Homeless individuals in the United States are subject to being [[arrest]]ed and held in jail for “quality of life” violations or for [[public intoxication]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=84347737&site=ehost-live|title = An Alternative to Incarcerating the Homeless|last = Marbut|first = Robert G.|date = November 2012|journal = American Jails|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 26|issue = 5|pages = 23–26}}</ref> In Hawaii, homeless people are banned from sitting or lying on the streets.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/07/01/carolina-jesus-hawaii_n_7700726.html|title = How One 'Mother Hen' In Hawaii Care for 63 Homeless People at a Time|last = Kaneya|first = Rui|date = 1 July 2015|work = The Huffington Post|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
=== LGBT people === The [[LGBT]] homeless are at increased risk of violence compared to other groups.<ref name=":6" /> [[Transgender]] people are also at danger of being placed into the incorrect shelters. In some cases, transgender women can be turned away from women's shelters.<ref name=":19">{{Cite news|url = http://www.13abc.com/home/headlines/Transgender-woman-upset-after-being-kicked-out-of-shelter-309397841.html|title = Transgender Woman Upset After Being Kicked Out of Shelter|last = |first = |date = 25 June 2015|work = 13 ABC|access-date = 17 December 2015|via = }}</ref> This can place their safety at risk.<ref name=":19" />
=== Men === In a national survey conducted in the United States the findings showed that of the surveyed homeless, two-thirds are men and most likely to be single adults between the ages of 25 and 54.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://www.nhchc.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/June2001HealingHands.pdf|title = Single Males: The Homeless Majority|last = |first = |date = June 2001|journal = Healing Hands|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 17 December 2015|page = 1|volume = 5|issue = 3}}</ref>
One out of every four men experiences domestic violence.<ref>{{cite web|title=|url=|website=http://www.ncadv.org/learn/statistics|accessdate=17 December 2015}}</ref> In addition, young men who have been abused as children are more likely to become homeless and are at risk of becoming chronically homeless if they are not living in a permanent situation by age 24.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://www.nhchc.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/June2001HealingHands.pdf|title = Between a Rock and a Hard Place|last = |first = |date = June 2001|journal = Healing Hands|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 17 December 2015|pages = 2–3|volume = 5|issue = 3}}</ref>
=== Women === Women are at great risk of both homelessness and poverty because they are most likely to bear child-rearing responsibilities and vulnerable to become victims of family members or “intimate partners.”<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=pbh&AN=48169023&site=ehost-live|title = 'Like a Prison!': Homeless Women's Narratives of Surviving Shelter|last = Deward|first = Sarah L.|date = March 2010|journal = Journal of Sociology & Social Welfare|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|last2 = Moe|first2 = Angela M.|issue = 1|volume = 37|pages = 115–135}}</ref> In a survey conducted in the 2013 showed that in an emergency shelter in [[Texas]], women were the majority population, though this is not a trend reflected in the majority of the country.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.news-journal.com/news/2013/feb/05/survey-more-women-than-men-in-area-homeless-shelte/|title = Survey: More Women Than Men in Area Homeless Shelters|last = Ward|first = Angela|date = 5 February 2013|work = Longview News-Journal|access-date = 17 December 2015|via = }}</ref>
Homeless women, both those with children and without, experience higher rates of physical illness than men.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=eric&AN=EJ955396&site=ehost-live|title = From Homelessness to Community: Psychological Integration of Women Who Have Experienced Homelessness|last = Nemiroff|first = Rebecca|date = 1 November 2011|journal = Journal of Community Psychology|doi = 10.1002/jcop.20486|pmid = |access-date = 23 July 2015|last2 = Aubry|first2 = Tim|issue = 8|subscription = yes|pages = 1003–1018|volume = 39|last3 = Klodawsky|first3 = Fran}}</ref> They are also more likely to be hyper-vigilant and have high levels of stress.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=88318694&site=ehost-live|title = Impacting Quality of Life at a Homeless Shelter: Measuring the Effectiveness of Say it Straight|last = Haag|first = Marcy|date = 4 January 2011|journal = International Journal of Interdisciplinary Social Sciences|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 24 July 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 5|issue = 12|pages = 195–203|last2 = Wood|first2 = Tom|last3 = Holloway|first3 = Linda}}</ref> Women seeking refuge from [[domestic violence]] are not always able to find rooms in shelters.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3149693/Women-fleeing-violent-partners-NSW-chance-winning-lottery-getting-bed-refuge.html|title = NSW Government is 'Open' to Increasing Services for Women Fleeing Violent Partners After it's Revealed Victims are 'Turned Away from Shelters' with Almost All at Full Capacity|last = Beers|first = Lucy-Mae|date = 4 July 2015|work = Daily Mail|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = |last2 = Thackray|first2 = Lucy|last3 = Tran|first3 = Cindy}}</ref> Some women have been turned away from homeless shelters because shelter staff believe that turning women away will stop people from having sex inside the shelter.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.wymt.com/content/news/Women-no-longer-accepted-at-homeless-shelter-after-sex-problem-361346571.html|title = Women No Longer Accepted at Homeless Shelter After 'Sex Problem'|last = Reighard|first = Angela|date = 9 December 2015|work = WYMT|access-date = 17 December 2015|via = }}</ref>
Homeless women who are of childbearing age also face unique [[Menstrual hygiene day|hygiene issues]] because of [[menstruation]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url = http://www.huf[21]fingtonpost.com/2015/01/14/homeless-women-tampons_n_6465230.html|title = For Homeless Women, Getting Their Period is One of the Most Difficult Challenges|last = Goldberg|first = Eleanor|date = 14 January 2015|work = The Huffington Post|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Homeless shelters have noted that both [[tampon]]s and [[Sanitary napkin|sanitary pads]] “top the list of needs at shelters” because of their high cost and because they are not donated often.<ref name=":5" />
== Alternative models and management philosophies ==
=== Housing first practice=== The homeless shelters across the country act merely as emergency shelter systems that can only hold a fraction of the rapidly increasing homeless population. The Housing First practice provides an alternative to the current network of homeless shelters. The program targets the large problem within the United States which is a lack of affordable housing. This methodology attempts to place homeless families back into independent living situations as quickly as possible. The Housing First practice has achieved success due the fact that homeless families are more responsive to social services support once when they are in their own housing. It provides crisis intervention, affordable rental housing, and gives each family a grace period of six months to a year of social service to allow the family to get back on their feet. The effectiveness of this concept is that it assists homeless families in identifying their needs and recognizing the choices they must make. From this point families can create better options for themselves and plan strategies for living on their own.<ref>http://www.beyondshelter.org/aaa_initiatives/ending_homelessness.shtml</ref>
===Empowerment model=== Some shelters propose “empowerment models,” where instead of serving “clients," they empower “participants.” The goal is to become agents in their own futures and destinies.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
Such models tend to focus on assisting participants to access their rights and to fulfill their responsibilities as citizens. Sometimes this includes contributing financially towards the provision of the shelters they are residing in. In Australia, legislation requires those residing in Government funded shelters to contribute a figure similar to 25% of their own income, in return for support and accommodation. Consequently, many shelters in Australia rely on participant contributions for as much as 20% of their budgets.<ref>Najidah Association Inc. Annual report, 2007.</ref>
===Religious shelters=== Another model is Dorothy's Place in Salinas, CA. It is actually a day center which coordinates with multiple church and synagogue congregations to link up to night time shelter opportunities. Dorothy's Place is closely affiliated with faith based community service groups, including the Franciscan Worker and Companions of the Way Interfaith Dharma community. They propose that they are in search of “possibilitarians,” a theme resonating with the prominent ministry of “possibility thinking” promoted by [[Reformed Church of America]] minister [[Robert H. Schuller|Robert Schuller]].
The Rescue Mission in [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Minnesota]] is an extreme example of helping the homeless through religion. In order to receive a free meal at the Rescue Mission, residents must first attend a [[Christian]] prayer service.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.milwaukeemag.com/2015/07/13/food-for-the-soul-homeless-milwaukee/|title = Food for the Soul|last = Hrodey|first = Matt|date = 13 July 2015|work = Milwaukee Magazine|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
The [[Salvation Army]] is a social support service organization that also functions as a religious group.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=45223892&site=ehost-live|title = Help for the Helpers|last = Young|first = Ben|date = November 2009|journal = Georgia Trend|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 24 July 2015|volume = 25|issue = 3|page = 18}}</ref> The programs of the Salvation Army are designed to assist women, children, elderly men, families, and those who are battling drug addictions.
=== Vehicles as shelter === Around the late 2000s, in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]] and other areas in [[California]], groups of recently homeless began to camp out in their cars in [[parking lot]]s with the coordinated support of a local non-profit group.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title = Homelessness|last = Fleck|first = Carole|publisher = Greenhaven Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780737759396|location = Farmington Hills, Michigan|pages = 31–32|chapter = Is Homelessness a Serious Problem?}}</ref> These individuals and families were often unable to afford rent or [[Mortgage loan|mortgage]], but still had jobs, cars, insurance and other types of support structures.<ref name=":7" /> In Santa Barbara, an estimated 55 individuals camped out every night in various private and public lots, some reserved for women only.<ref name=":7" /> As more people began to camp in their vehicles, California cities began to pass laws against sleeping in vehicles, like the 2013 ordinance passed in [[Palo Alto, California|Palo Alto]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url = http://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/2014/11/18/palo-alto-strikes-down-car-camping-ban|title = Palo Alto Strikes Down Car-Camping Ban|last = Sheyner|first = Gennady|date = 18 November 2014|work = Palo Alto Online|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> However, many of these laws in different municipalities were later struck down in higher courts as [[Constitutionality|unconstitutional]],<ref name=":8" /> like the [[Los Angeles]] ban which was judged by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|9th Circuit Court of Appeals]] in 2014.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url = http://www.scpr.org/news/2015/07/23/53164/homeless-living-in-cars-baffle-neighborhoods/|title = Number of Homeless Living in Cars, RVs in LA Grows|last = Tam|first = Susanica|date = 23 July 2015|work = Southern California Public Radio|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> Some cities chose to repeal their own bans on sleeping in vehicles.<ref name=":8" /> In Los Angeles in 2015, approximately 9,500 homeless have turned their cars into homes.<ref name=":9" /> In [[Hawaii]], a [[Honolulu]]-based company is retrofitting five retired city [[bus]]es into mobile shelters which provide a place to sleep and get a shower.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/06/12/hawaii-mobile-homeless-shelters_n_7571924.html|title = Hawaii to Convert Retired Buses Into Fleet of Mobil Homeless Shelters, Showers|last = Goldberg|first = Eleanor|date = 12 June 2015|work = The Huffington Post|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
== Community attitudes == Community attitude towards homeless shelters varies widely, but one study found that older people, men, homeowners and all people making larger incomes were often adverse to the concept of homeless shelters in general.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Putting Health Into Place|last = Takahashi|first = Lois M.|publisher = Syracuse University Press|year = 1998|isbn = 0815627688|location = Syracuse, New York|pages = 153–157|chapter = Concepts of Difference in Community Health|editor-last = Kearns|editor-first = Robin A.|editor-last2 = Gesler|editor-first2 = Wilbert M.}}</ref> [[Calgary]] neighborhoods recognize the need for shelters, but many don't want to situate a shelter near their own homes.<ref name=":1" /> A similar response came from residents in [[Oahu]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/29524570/state-homeless-shelters-controversial-now-and-20-years-ago|title = State Homeless Shelters Controversial Now and 20 Years Ago|last = Kerr|first = Keoki|date = 10 July 2015|work = Hawaii News Now|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = }}</ref> In communities such as Portland, Oregon, where the weather can be quite harsh, there is an extensive network of supporters. These operate an informal restaurant, the "Sisters of the Road" cafe, which supports both homeless shelter residents and also some unsheltered persons. At the opposite end of the spectrum, jurisdictions such as [[Santa Barbara, California]], feature ongoing disputes in an often highly adversarial mode.<ref>Santa Barbara Independent, January 2011</ref> Disputes have even reached such schemes as re-arranging benches on city sidewalks to discourage panhandlers. In another 2011 incident, an eight unit [[supportive housing]] project which had been approved was called back onto city council agenda the following week in order to allow approximately 35 public comments pro and con, despite the fact that the measure had just been approved.
There have at times been concerns raised about the transmission of diseases in the homeless population housed in shelters, although public health professionals contend that such concerns are inflated.<ref>Najidah Association Inc. Annual return to the Dept. of Communities 2006</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_id=13923&p_table=FEDERAL_REGISTER |title=Occupational Exposure to Tuberculosis |publisher= [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] notice |year=1997 }}</ref> In addition, a study published in 2014 conducted in [[Marseille|Marseille, France]] found that respiratory illnesses in homeless shelters were not significantly different from the general population.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1756-0500/7/81|title = Respiratory viruses within homeless shelters in Marseille, France|last = Thiberville|first = Simon-djamel|date = 5 February 2014|journal = BMC Research Notes|doi = 10.1186/1756-0500-7-81|pmid = |access-date = 23 July 2015|volume = 7|issue = 81|last2 = Salez|first2 = Nicolas|last3 = Benkouiten|last4 = Badiaga|first3 = Samir|first4 = Sekene|last5 = Charrel|first5 = Remi|last6 = Brouqui|first6 = Philippe}}</ref> In addition, during the peak [[influenza]] months, the shelter occupants did not test positive for the flu virus and the researchers hypothesize that being isolated from others may have been the reason they were virus-free.<ref name=":10" /> However, outbreaks of [[tuberculosis]] in have been reported occurring in shelters within three large [[Ohio]] cities in the 1990s.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Epidemic of Health Care Worker Injury: An Epidemiology|last = |first = |publisher = CRC Press|year = 1999|isbn = 0849333822|location = |pages = 78|editor-first = William|editor-last = Charney|editor-last2 = Fragala|editor-first2 = Guy|chapter = Occupational Exposure to Tuberculosis}}</ref>
A question has been raised as just how much money donated to the charities that run the shelters actually gets to the homeless people and the required services. In many cases, there is a large overhead in administrative costs, which compromise the money for their homeless clients.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.bostonnow.com/news/local/2007/08/13/the-high-price-of-giving|title = The High Price of Giving|last = O'Brien|first = James|date = 13 August 2007|work = Boston Now|access-date = 23 July 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071111183241/http://www.bostonnow.com/news/local/2007/08/13/the-high-price-of-giving|archive-date = 11 November 2007}}</ref>
=== Internal problems in homeless shelters === There is sometimes corruption and theft by the employees of a shelter as evidenced by a 2011 investigative report by [[WFXT|FOX 25 TV]] in [[Boston]] wherein a number of Boston public shelter employees were found stealing large amounts of food over a period of time from the shelter's kitchen for their private use and catering.<ref>Beaudet, Mike, [http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/undercover/money-food-taken-from-city-kitchen-20110222 "FOX Undercover: Employees implicated in thefts from local homeless"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303140612/http://www.myfoxboston.com/dpp/news/undercover/money-food-taken-from-city-kitchen-20110222 |date=2011-03-03 }}, FOX 25 TV, Boston, Tuesday, 22 Feb 2011</ref><ref>Smith, Stephen, [http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2011/02/23/shelter_kitchen_theft_prevalent_report_says/ "Shelter kitchen theft prevalent, report says"], ''The Boston Globe'', February 23, 2011</ref> Residents have reported that personal items, such as underwear, were stolen by other residents while they were occupied.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Shelter: Where Harvard Meets the Homeless|last = Seider|first = Scott|publisher = The Continuum International Publishing Group|year = 2010|isbn = 9781441137371|location = New York|pages = 33–34}}</ref>
Shelters can become dangerously overcrowded when too many occupants are allowed entry to the shelter.<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/06/nyregion/sylvias-place-faces-licensing-problems.html?_r=0|title = A Church. A Shelter. Is It Safe?|last = Thrasher|first = Steven W.|date = 4 November 2011|work = The New York Times|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
Shelters sometimes are unable to meet state standards for occupancy, such as testing fire sprinklers or ensuring that exits are clearly marked.<ref name=":11" /> In New York city, 2015, the state withheld funding from many shelters which did not meet standards or which had poor conditions.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/state-withholds-funds-from-some-new-york-city-homeless-shelters-1431482602|title = State Withholds Funds From Some New York City Homeless Shelters|last = Dawsey|first = Josh|date = 12 May 2015|work = The Wall Street Journal|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
Shelter employees are sometimes at risk from violence perpetrated by the residents they are serving.<ref>{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015%EF%BF%BC/04/30/nyregion/bronx-homeless-shelter-killing.html?gwh=80DDD7BE14E14C13FF1291CDC7859CCF&gwt=pay|title = Police Describe Ex-Resident's Calculated Plan to Attack Bronx Homeless Shelter's Director|last = Hu|first = Winnie|date = 29 April 2015|work = The New York Times|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> In order to address problems faced by employees who are trying to help the homeless in New York, the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] increased [[Security guard|security]] at some shelters and conducted security assessments of shelters in 2015.<ref name=":17">{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/07/nyregion/new-york-city-works-to-improve-safety-of-homeless-shelter-workers.html|title = New York City Takes Steps to Increase the Safety of Employees at Homeless Shelters|last = Hu|first = Winnie|date = 6 July 2015|work = The New York Times|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> While many employees of shelters know that there is a risk when working in high-crime neighborhoods or with individuals who are mentally ill, they continue to work at homeless shelters because they feel that they are performing a public service akin to the [[police]] or [[firefighter]]s.<ref name=":17" />
=== External problems === Several problems emerge when a homeless shelter is present. Homeless shelters have been argued by some to have a negative effect on nearby businesses.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=95939242&site=ehost-live|title = Investing in the Homeless Corridor|last = Nishimura|first = Scott|date = 28 April 2014|journal = Fort Worth Business Press|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 26|issue = 16|pages = 1, 23–25}}</ref> Businesses for years have complained that they frequently witness pedestrians being stopped outside their stores by homeless people begging for money. Such instances have led to the creation of local laws that prohibit “aggressive panhandling.” Another problem is that it is often difficult to decide on where a homeless shelter should be built and how to zone the area where a shelter can be built.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.kimatv.com/home/video/City-of-Yakima-struggles-to-find-a-solution-for-homeless-shelter-zoning-318085811.html|title = City of Yakima Struggles to Find a Solution for Homeless Shelter Zoning|last = Ramos|first = Claudia|date = 21 July 2015|work = KIMA TV|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150723095630/http://www.kimatv.com/home/video/City-of-Yakima-struggles-to-find-a-solution-for-homeless-shelter-zoning-318085811.html|archivedate = 23 July 2015|df = }}</ref>
Neighborhoods, as well as schools, argue that homeless shelters bring in bad elements to their surroundings. There are additionally far too many shelters that have become nothing but housing facilities; they fail to provide job training or education that would assist the homeless population with gaining their own housing. Housing through homeless shelters offers no lasting solutions, just temporary ones. Drugs and alcohol also tend to surround homeless shelters. Most shelters prohibit residential use of illegal drugs and alcohol, but enforcement is sporadic in many locations. Lastly, no classification system for shelters has been put into effect. There are no mechanisms or facilities to separate those who have mental illnesses from the rest of the shelter population.<ref>Skolnick, Jerome H., and Elliott Currie. Crisis in American Institutions. 14th ed. Boston, MA: Pearson/Allyn and Bacon, 2007. Print.</ref>
== United States == In the [[United States]], the "shelter movement" began to grow significantly during the 1970s when there was a high rate of [[unemployment]], housing costs were rising and individuals with severe [[Mental disorder|mental illnesses]] were being deinstitutionalized.<ref name=":3" /> In the 1980s, homelessness was becoming a "national epidemic" in the United States and helping professionals created shelters as "temporary havens."<ref name=":15">{{Cite book|title = Homelessness|last = Culhane|first = Dennis|publisher = Greenhaven Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780737759396|location = Farmington Hills, Michigan|chapter = Better Information About Homelessness Means Better Strategies|pages = 177}}</ref> Shelter occupation had more than doubled by the late 1980s and it doubled again by 2000.<ref name=":15" /> Statistics from 2011 show that "on a given night in January 2010, 407,966 individuals were housed inside homeless shelters, transitional housing or on the streets.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://homeless.samhsa.gov/ResourceFiles/hrc_factsheet.pdf|title = Current Statistics on the Prevalence and Characteristics of People Experiencing Homelessness in the United States|date = July 2011|accessdate = 17 December 2015|website = Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration|publisher = |last = Paquette|first = Kristen}}</ref> Alternatively, [[Jail|jails]] have been used for healthcare enrollment by citizens in certain states.<ref>https://www.urban.org/sites/default/files/publication/86666/using_jail_to_enroll_low_income_men_in_medicaid.pdf</ref> Simultaneously, organizations such as [[Interfaith Services]] have provided low income postal service boxes to aid in receiving missing ID cards obtained by pro-Bono legal service organizations such as the Colorado ID project.<ref>https://www.interfaithofnc.com/about</ref><ref>http://coloradolegalservices.org</ref>
Homeless shelters need to provide a variety of services to diverse residents. Homeless shelters, like La Posada Providencia in [[San Benito, Texas]], may also house [[Refugee|asylum seekers]], mainly from [[Mexico]], [[Central America]] and [[South America]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=100169989&site=ehost-live|title = Seeking Refuge|last = Rose|first = Ananda|date = 9 January 2015|journal = Commonweal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|volume = 142|issue = 1|pages = 10–12|subscription = yes}}</ref> Shelters also provide [[outreach]] to residents who are unable to use a shelter or who choose not to use a shelter.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://wishtv.com/2015/01/07/team-effort-to-help-indys-homeless-survive-the-cold/|title = Team Effort to Help Indy's Homeless Survive the Cold|last = Grove|first = Dustin|date = 7 January 2015|work = Wish TV|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = }}</ref> Outreach may include providing clothing for cold weather or food. Very few shelters have case managers that locate resources locally, such as rides to a department of social services where [[Medicaid|healthcare]] can be acquired.
Most shelters typically expect residents to exit in the morning and occupy themselves elsewhere during the day, returning for an evening meal and to sleep. During times of inclement weather, shelters may provide services outside of their normal hours.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nbcneb.com/home/headlines/Homeless-Battle-Heat-Through-Help-From-Homeless-Shelters-315123761.html|title = Homeless Battle Heat Through Help From Homeless Shelters|last = Champ|first = Anastasia|date = 15 July 2015|work = NBC Nebraska|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = }}</ref> [[Curfew]]s vary widely but tend to be at an earlier hour than adults typically might return to a home. There are also daytime-only homeless shelters, where the homeless can go when they cannot stay inside at their night time sleeping shelter during the day. Such an early model of a daytime homeless shelter providing multi-faceted services is [[Saint Francis House (Boston)|Saint Francis House]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] which was officially founded in 1984. It was based on the [[Settlement movement|settlement house]], [[Clubhouse Model of Psychosocial Rehabilitation|clubhouse]] and [[Community centre|community center]] support and social service models.
In the United States, the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD) has shown in recent studies that about 5 million Americans qualify to use homeless shelters. As poverty levels continue to rise, it is estimated that the number of homeless shelters, in particular in the United States, will continue to rise.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.homelessshelterssite.org/|title = Homeless Shelters|date = |accessdate = 22 July 2015|website = Homeless Shelters|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Based on a survey of 24 U.S. cities the average stay in a homeless shelter was found to be on average about seven months out of the year.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Homelessness|last = National Coalition for the Homeless|first = |publisher = Greenhaven Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780737759396|location = Farmington Hills, Michigan|pages = 71|chapter = Multiple Factors Contribute to Homelessness}}</ref>
=== Statistics of homeless population within the United States === {{Main|Homelessness in the United States}}
A study by the [[The National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty|National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty]] estimates that 2.3 to 3.5 million Americans experience homelessness annually. [[Alaska]], [[California]], [[Nevada]], [[Oregon]], [[Colorado]], and [[Hawaii]] are the states with the highest concentration of homeless people. Around 1.5 million children or one of out every 50 children in America are homeless. Many Americans suffer from the state of “chronic homelessness,” which is where an individual has a disabling condition who has been continuously homeless for over a year or has been homeless on at least four different instances within four years. About 23% of the homeless population has been tagged as “chronic homeless.” Veterans also represent close to 40% of homeless men within the United States. [[Race and ethnicity in the United States|Racial demographics]] of the Homeless Population of the United States can be represented as:
* Whites: 39% * African-Americans: 42% * Hispanics: 13% * Native Americans: 4% * Asians: 2% Approximately 40% of all homeless youth in the United States identify as [[LGBT]] (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender).<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url = http://nationalhomeless.org/issues/lgbt/|title = LGBT Homelessness|date = |accessdate = 22 July 2015|website = National Coalition for the Homeless|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In [[San Francisco]], approximately 29% of all the homeless in that city are on the LGBT spectrum.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=70764|title = The Bay Area Reporter|last = Hemmelgarn|first = Seth|date = 23 July 2015|work = The Bay Area Reporter|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> The [[National Center for Transgender Equality]] reports that 1 in 5 [[transgender]] individuals has experienced being homeless at least once in their lives.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://transequality.org/issues/housing-homelessness|title = Housing & Homelesslessness|date = |accessdate = 22 July 2015|website = National Center for Transgender Equality|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Pet ownership among the homeless varies, but estimates indicate that about 5 and 10 percent of the homeless in the United States have a pet.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nevadabusiness.com/2015/07/pets-homeless-embarks-sixth-annual-give-dog-bone-week/|title = Pets of the Homeless Embarks on Sixth Annual Give a Dog a Bone Week|last = Walquist|first = Scott|date = 15 July 2015|work = Nevada Business|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
Homelessness appears to be largely concentrated within urban areas. Central cities hold 71% of the homeless population while the suburbs have 21% of the homeless population. Only 9% of the homeless class can be located within rural areas.
===Operations and role in U.S. society===
Homeless shelters are usually operated by a [[non-profit agency]] or a municipal agency, or are associated with a church. They almost always have Section 501(c)3 corporate organization with a [[Board of directors|Board of Directors]] pulled from various sectors of the community. Often, such Boards include clergy, elected officials, and even shelter residents and people from the surrounding community.
Shelters which are funded by the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD) require residents to have identification.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.tucsonweekly.com/tucson/dignity/Content?oid=5546437|title = Dignity|last = Taracena|first = Maria Ines|date = 16 July 2015|work = Tucson Weekly|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
Homeless shelters often provide other services to the community at large. The classic example is the [[soup kitchen]] for persons who are not staying at the shelter. Others include [[support group]]s, and/or [[substance abuse]] treatment. If they do not offer any of these services, they can usually refer their clients to agencies that do. [[Supportive housing]] integrates services in a more assertive fashion. The typical pathway through the interlocking system is that a person may start in a shelter and move through [[transitional housing]] into [[supportive housing]] and finally independent housing.
Centers in the United States are also often coordinated with outside programs both for their mission-specific operations and for ancillary services. For communication of their availability, most coordinate with the Federally mandated 2-1-1 or the 3-1-1 phone information system which allow needy persons to find out where shelters are located.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} For transportation to shelters, some offer free transportation,[15] particularly in cases of persons being released from jail. Some jails have specific staff assigned to placement of persons being released. {{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
=== List of national organizations in the U.S supporting homeless shelters === Across the United States there are several national organizations that assist in the founding and the upkeep of homeless shelters. The main national organizations are: * The National Alliance to End Homelessness * [[The Salvation Army]] * The National Coalition for the Homeless * The Emergency Food and Shelter Program (United Way) * The [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]] * [[Feeding America]] * [[Housing Assistance Council]] * Help USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.homeless.org.au/directory/shelters.htm|title = Homeless Shelters and Programs|date = |accessdate = 22 July 2015|website = Homeless.org|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
===United States libraries=== Homeless shelters often work with other organizations in order to support and help the homeless improve their situations, including libraries.<ref>American Library Association. (2014). ''Outreach Resources for Services to Poor and Homeless People''. Retrieved From http://www.ala.org/advocacy/diversity/outreachtounderservedpopulations/servicespoor</ref> They often work with the coalition to grant a temporary library card for homeless coalition members who can use a shelter as a local address. This is intending to give new patrons the opportunity to utilize the computer services, books, programs, and more that the library offers.<ref>Community Legal Aid. (2011). ''Library changes borrowing policy for homeless.'' Retrieved From: {{cite web |url=http://www.communitylegal.org/work/news/article091406 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140331213210/http://www.communitylegal.org/work/news/article091406 |archivedate=2014-03-31 |df= }}</ref>
=== Government assistance programs in the United States === Homeless individuals within the United States are assisted through various Federal programs. Examples include the Social Security Disability Insurance (SSD) and the Social Security Supplemental Income (SSI) programs. Such applicants may qualify through their medical records. The Social Security Disability Insurance service extends benefits to families if they have earned sufficient work “credits.” The Social Security Supplemental Income service offers financial assistance towards individuals in need who are disabled, blind or elderly.
[[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|HUD]] estimates that it costs $60,000 each year to house a homeless family in a shelter.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url = https://www.npr.org/2015/07/07/420537082/for-homeless-families-quick-exit-from-shelters-is-only-a-temporary-fix|title = For Homeless Families, Quick Exit From Shelter is Only a Temporary Fix|last = Fessler|first = Pam|date = 7 July 2015|work = National Public Radio (NPR)|access-date = 22 July 2015|via = }}</ref> Because of this, HUD has various programs in place to help families, including rapid rehousing and permanent housing [[voucher]]s.<ref name=":4" /> Housing vouchers from HUD are considered especially important for helping to prevent families with children from becoming homeless and also to help these families be able to leave the shelter system permanently.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Homelessness|last = Sard|first = Barbara|publisher = Greenhaven Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780737759396|location = Farmington Hills, Michigan|chapter = Government Housing Vouchers Help Homeless Families Best|pages = 131}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]] is solely aimed at helping [[homeless veterans in the United States|homeless veterans]]. Although this organization assists a specific concentration of individuals, it currently constitutes the largest network of homeless treatment within the United States.{{Citation needed|date = July 2015}}
== Other countries ==
=== Australia === In [[Australia]], due to government funding requirements, most homelessness services fill the role of both daytime and night time shelters. Shelters develop empowerment based "wrap around" services in which residents are case managed and supported in their efforts to become self-reliant. An example of such a service provider in this area in Australia is [[Najidah (Australia)|Najidah]].
Youth refuges in Australia provide both a residential setting for crisis accommodation as well as case management to assist young people to live independently. Youth refuges are a relatively new form of homeless shelters. In New South Wales the early refuges include [[Caretakers Cottage]], Young People's Refuge, Taldamunde Youth Services, all founded in the mid-1970s.<ref>Coffey, Michael. "What Ever Happened to the Revolution? Activism and the Early Days of Youth Refuges in NSW." Parity. Volume 19, Issue 10. Another Country: Histories of Homelessness. Council to Homeless Persons. (2006): 23-25.</ref>
=== Canada === [[Canada]] has an estimated homeless population somewhere between 150,000 and 300,000 people as reported in 2014.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bth&AN=101069146&site=ehost-live|title = Prevalence of Gambling Problems Among the Clients of a Toronto Homeless Shelter|last = Matheson|first = Flora|date = June 2014|journal = Journal of Gambling Studies|doi = 10.1007/s10899-014-9452-7|pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 30|issue = 2|last2 = Devotta|first2 = Kimberly|last3 = Wendaferew|first3 = Aklilu|last4 = Pedersen|first4 = Cheryl|pages=537–546}}</ref> Canada has responded to an increase in homelessness by increasing the amount of shelter space available to individuals.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=59993646&site=ehost-live|title = Siting Homeless Shelters in Calgary: Impacts of the New Land Use Bylaw and the Local Development Process|last = Muller|first = Larissa|date = 2010|journal = Canadian Journal of Urban Research|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|last2 = Kuzmak|first2 = Natasha|issue = 2|volume = 19|pages = 1–22|subscription = yes}}</ref> A study done in Canada also found that individuals entering shelters and [[drop-in center]]s experienced a loss of their own sense of [[personhood]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ896178.pdf|title = Making Meaning Together: An Exploratory Study of Therapeutic Conversation Between Helping Professionals and Homeless Shelter Residents|last = Walsh|first = Christine A.|date = July 2010|journal = The Qualitative Report|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|last2 = Rutherford|first2 = Gayle E.|volume = 15|issue = 4|last3 = Sarafincian|last4 = Sellmer|first3 = Kristina N.|first4 = Sabine E. R.}}</ref> Therapeutic Conversation therapy has been tested and found successful in [[Calgary]] with a small group of homeless shelter residents in improving their mental health outcomes.<ref name=":2" /> Calgary has seen an increase in the amount of homelessness, partly due to the "lack of affordable rental units."<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bth&AN=98884689&site=ehost-live|title = Resolving Homelessness in Calgary|last = Parker|first = David|date = 1 October 2014|journal = Business in Calgary|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 24 July 2015|volume = 24|issue = 10|page = 34|subscription = yes}}</ref>
A nationwide volunteer group in Canada, the Angels in the Night, sponsored by Invis-Mortgage Intelligence, donates cold-weather clothes and other supplies to the homeless, visiting shelters and individuals on the streets.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bwh&AN=201212110700CANADANWCANADAPR.C7895&site=ehost-live|title = A Decade's Worth of Warmth and Caring|last = |first = |date = 11 December 2012|work = Canada Newswire|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
In 2015, [[Clean the World]] began a Canadian Operations Center in [[Montreal]] order to supply soap for homeless shelters.<ref name=":16">{{Cite news|url = http://www.prweb.com/releases/2015/07/prweb12856847.htm|title = Clean the World Opens Canadian Operations Center to Support Growth and Expansion|last = |first = |date = 21 July 2015|work = PR Web|access-date = 23 July 2015|via = }}</ref> Clean the World distributes and recycles hygiene supplies such as soap and shampoo.<ref name=":16" />
=== China === In [[China]], homeless estimates vary, since the Social Welfare Department does not consider those living in temporary shelters to be "homeless."<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1461195/1400-homeless-hong-kong-double-government-estimate-study|title = 1,400 Homeless Sleeping on Hong Kong's Streets, Double government estimates|last = Kao|first = Ernest|date = 31 March 2014|work = South China Morning Post|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref> There may be approximately 1 to 1.5 million homeless children who have left their families because of extreme poverty, family issues or abuse.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.businessinsider.com/china-1-million-homeless-children-2012-11|title = There Are One Million Children Living On the Streets in China, And They're Totally Alone|last = |first = |date = 22 November 2012|work = Business Insider|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
In the city of [[Dali City|Dali]], there is an annual conference for "beggars."<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/peoplesdaily/article-3086424/Chinese-city-inundated-beggars-homeless-gather-annual-conference-beg-busk-feast-together.html|title = Chinese City Inundated by Beggars as Homeless Gather for 'Annual Conference' to Beg, Busk and Feast Together|last = Chow|first = Edward|date = 18 May 2015|work = Daily Mail|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = |last2 = Charlton|first2 = Corey}}</ref> In 2014, a government-sponsored shelter in [[Henan]] province which houses 20 homeless individuals was under scrutiny for tying children to trees and providing inadequate sleeping areas.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1663544/chinese-homeless-shelter-tied-children-trees-case-they-run-away|title = Chinese Homeless Shelter Ties Mentally Ill Boy to Tree to 'Stop Him Running Around'|last = Chen|first = Andrea|date = 17 December 2014|work = South China Morning Post|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = |last2 = Yu|first2 = Alan}}</ref>
=== India === India defines homelessness as not being in residence of a "census house" which must be a structure with a roof.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=97324591&site=ehost-live|title = Urban Homelessness and the Right to Water and Sanitation: Experiences from India's Cities|last = Walters|first = Vicky|date = 2014|journal = Water Policy|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 23 July 2015|volume = 14|issue = 4|pages = 755–772|subscription = yes}}</ref>
In [[India]], youth can become homeless because of [[child abandonment]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=103663089&site=ehost-live|title = Maltreatment Experiences as Predictors of Self-Esteem and Psychiatric Morbidity Among Sheltered Homeless Adolescents|last = Devi|first = Rachna|date = 2015|journal = Journal of Indian Association for Child & Adolescent Mental Health|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 22 July 2015|subscription = yes|last2 = Sharma|first2 = Vasundhra|issue = 3|volume = 11|pages = 206–232|last3 = Shekhar|first3 = Chandra}}</ref> Youth in [[Jammu]] and [[Kashmir]] who live in shelters reported high prevalence of emotional and physical abuse, and emotional and physical neglect while living in homeless shelters.<ref name=":0" />
Homeless individuals and families in India face challenges accessing water and hygiene services. A 2011 Census of India found that safe drinking water coverage in urban areas is at 91.9% while regular sanitation access is at 81.4%.<ref name=":12" /> There is a significant lack of housing in major urban areas in India.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|url = http://theglobaljournals.com/gra/file.php?val=August_2014_1408104924__16.pdf|title = Homeless Population in India: A Study|last = Kumuda|first = D.|date = August 2014|journal = GJRA - Global Journal for Research Analysis|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 23 July 2015|pages = 54–55|volume = 3|issue = 8}}</ref> People come from the rural part of India to look for work and when there are no accommodations for housing build their own shelters, often known as "hutments."<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=3436804&site=ehost-live|title = India's Moral Dilemma Over Evicting Poor|last = Marquand|first = Robert|date = 15 August 2000|journal = Christian Science Monitor|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 23 July 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 92|issue = 185}}</ref>
==== Statistics of homeless population within India ==== {{Main|Homelessness in India}}
According to the 2011 Census, there were 1.77 million homeless people in India, or 0.15% of the country's total population.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jha|first1=Somesh|title=1.77 million people live without shelter, albeit the number decline over a decade|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/1-77-million-people-live-without-shelter-albeit-the-number-decline-over-a-decade-113120600835_1.html|publisher=''Business Standard''|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref> In India, the cities with the greatest number of homeless individuals and families are [[Mumbai|Greater Mumbai]], [[Delhi]], [[Kolkata]], [[Chennai]], and [[Bangalore]].<ref name=":13" />
=== Japan === The number of homeless individuals in [[Japan]] as recorded in 2003, was around 25,296.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2003/07/10/national/homeless-shelters-presence-profits-irk-neighbors/#.VbLcD3UVhBc|title = Homeless Shelters' Presence, Profits Irk Neighbors|last = Matsubara|first = Hiroshi|date = 10 July 2003|work = The Japan Times|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref> Numbers of those without homes have been "increasing dramatically" since the "[[Economic bubble|bubble economy]]" collapsed in the 1990s.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bth&AN=34899392&site=ehost-live|title = What Determines the Spatial Distribution of Homeless People in Japan?|last = Suzuki|first = Wataru|date = 20 October 2008|journal = Applied Economics Letters|doi = 10.1080/13504850600972394|pmid = |access-date = 24 July 2015|volume = 15|issue = 13|pages = 1023–1026|subscription = yes}}</ref> In [[Tokyo]], around 2007, many homeless individuals were cleared out of their temporary residences in city parks.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.boston.com/news/world/articles/2007/09/23/clothed_clean_and_homeless_in_japan/|title = Clothed, Clean, and Homeless in Japan|last = Harden|first = Blaine|date = 23 September 2007|work = The Washington Post|publisher = The Boston Globe|via = }}</ref> In 2011, the [[earthquake]] and [[tsunami]] left many individuals homeless and living in shelters.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://hereandnow.wbur.org/2011/04/01/japan-shelter-tsunami|title = Japan's Newly Homeless Continue to Make Do In Shelters|last = |first = |date = 1 April 2011|work = WBUR - Boston's NPR News Station|access-date = 24 July 2015|via = }}</ref>
=== United Kingdom === "Sleeping rough" or "rough sleeping" is terminology in the [[United Kingdom]] for sleeping without shelter.<ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url = http://www.crisis.org.uk/pages/rough-sleeping.html|title = Rough Sleeping|date = |accessdate = 24 July 2015|website = Crisis|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In addition, "not all homeless people are entitled to housing."<ref name=":18" /> Shelters like 'Jimmy's', in Cambridge, provide access to those who would otherwise be "sleeping rough", offering temporary accommodation and support services in the basement of a [[Baptists|Baptist]] Church in the city centre.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=9212919&site=ehost-live|title = An Action Research Project in a Night Shelter for Rough Sleepers|last = Payne|first = J.|date = 1 February 2002|journal = Journal of Psychiatric & Mental Health Nursing|doi = 10.1046/j.1351-0126.2001.00450.x|pmid = |access-date = 24 July 2015|volume = 9|issue = 1|pages = 95–101}}</ref>

The '''Kern County child abuse cases''' started the [[day care sexual abuse hysteria]] of the 1980s in [[Kern County, California]].<ref name=nyt1>{{cite news |first= Maggie|last= Jones|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Who Was Abused? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/19/magazine/19KIDSL.html?pagewanted=print&position= |quote=There are several ways to view the small white house on Center Street in [[Bakersfield, California]]. From one perspective it's just another low-slung home in a working-class neighborhood, with a front yard, brown carpeting, a TV in the living room. |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 19, 2004 |accessdate=2007-08-21 }}</ref> The cases involved claims of paedophile-sex-ring-performed [[Satanic ritual abuse]], with as many as 60 children testifying they had been abused. At least 36 people were convicted and most of them spent years imprisoned. Thirty-four convictions were overturned on appeal. The district attorney responsible for the convictions was [[Ed Jagels]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://truthinjustice.org/ed-jagels.htm |title=Mean Justice - Dirty Secrets |website=Truthinjustice.org |date= |accessdate=2016-11-18}}</ref> who was sued by at least one of those whose conviction was overturned,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aele.org/law/2003LRAUG/mvc.html|title=Modahl v. County of Kern|website=Aele.org|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> and who remained in office until 2009.<ref name=edj/> Two convicts died in prison, unable to clear their names.
==History== In 1982, Alvin and Debbie McCuan's two daughters, coached by their step-grandmother Mary Ann Barbour, who had custody of them, alleged they had been abused by their parents, and accused them of being part of a sex ring that included Scott and Brenda Kniffen. The Kniffens' two sons also claimed to have been abused. No physical evidence was ever found. The McCuans and Kniffens were convicted in 1984 and given a combined sentence of over 1000 years in prison.<ref name=rt>{{cite web |url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/ra_baker.htm |title=Kern County ritual abuse cases |accessdate=2007-08-26 |quote=The triggering incident occurred in 1980 when Becky McCuan disclosed that her grandfather, Rod Phelps, had touched her inappropriately. The family doctor confirmed the abuse. |publisher=Religious Tolerance }}</ref> The convictions were overturned in 1996 and the two couples were released. In 2001, a TV movie about the Kniffens titled ''Just Ask My Children'' was aired on [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0280474/|title=Just Ask My Children|date=10 September 2001|publisher=|via=IMDb}}</ref>
Six similar cases occurred throughout Kern County. For instance, the testimony of five young boys was the prosecution's key evidence in a trial in which four defendants were convicted. John Stoll, a 41-year-old carpenter, received the longest sentence of the group: 40 years for 17 counts of lewd and lascivious conduct. "It never happened," Ed Sampley, one of the accusers, told a ''New York Times'' reporter in 2004. He claimed he had lied about Stoll. Stoll was in prison for 19 years before his conviction was reversed.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2004/may/01/local/me-stoll1 Conviction reversed after 19 years], [[Los Angeles Times]], John Johnson, May 1, 2004. Retrieved 11 October 2014.</ref> In 2009, Stoll sued Kern County and was awarded $5 million in compensation.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090930214951/http://www.wrongfulconvictionlawsuitdefense.com/2009/09/articles/news/john-stoll-to-receive-5m-settlement-in-20-year-wrongful-conviction-case-featured-in-the-documentary-witch-hunt/ Web.archive.org]</ref> The county paid out nearly $10 million to settle claims made by the former prisoners and the alleged victims.<ref name=edj>{{cite news|title=Crusading Calif. D.A. retires, leaves painful wake|author=Garance Burke|publisher=Associated Press|date=2009-11-15}}</ref> A documentary titled ''Witch Hunt'', which focused primarily on Stoll's case, was produced and released in 2007. MSNBC also made a documentary on John Stoll and the Kern County cases.
Sampley and three other former accusers returned in 2004 to the courthouse where they had testified against Stoll, this time to say that Stoll never molested them. In their late 20s, each of them said he always knew the truth—that Stoll had never touched them.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/19/magazine/19KIDSL.html|title=Who Was Abused?|date=19 September 2004|work=The New York Times}}</ref> However, Stoll's son has "continued to say that he had been molested."<ref name=Logan>{{cite news|last=Logan |first=Jessica |title=Prosecutor's fire makes her either loved or loathed |publisher=The Bakersfield Californian |date=2005-05-31 |url=http://www.bakersfield.com/862/story/100201.html |accessdate=2008-07-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827235257/http://bakersfield.com/862/story/100201.html |archivedate=August 27, 2008 }}</ref> In the case, the only defendant with a previous conviction of molestation was Grant Self, who rented Stoll's pool house briefly.<ref name=Branco>{{cite news|last=Branco|first=Shellie|title=Ruling puts man back in hospital|publisher=The Bakersfield Californian|date=2007-04-18|url=http://www.bakersfield.com/619/story/122888.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113056/http://www.bakersfield.com/619/story/122888.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-04|accessdate=2008-07-11}}</ref> John Stoll had to wait until 2004 for the reversal of his convictions, but was released on the new testimony. Self was sent to a mental hospital for sexual offenders because he had two prior convictions for child molestation. Self was freed in 2009.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160308023041/http://www.bakersfield.com/news/local/x1034552768/man-sues-county-over-molestation-ring-prosecution Web.archive.org]</ref> He was re-arrested in 2012 on suspicion of child molestation in Oregon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bakersfieldcalifornian.com/local/x365558195/County-settles-last-of-molestation-conviction-lawsuits|title=Kern County settles last of molestation conviction suits|work=The Bakersfield Californian|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> In July 2013, Self pleaded guilty to sexually abusing three young boys and was sentenced to five years and 10 months in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.umich.edu/special/exoneration/Pages/casedetail.aspx?caseid=4163|title=Grant Self|publisher=|accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref>
Prior to the start of the Kern County child abuse cases, several local social workers had attended a training seminar that foregrounded satanic ritual abuse as a major element in child sexual abuse, and had used the now-debunked memoir ''[[Michelle Remembers]]'' as training material.<ref>[https://archive.is/20110522150523/http://members.shaw.ca/imaginarycrimes/michelleremembers.htm Archive.is]</ref>

The '''Khandeyar''' are one of the two groups of the [[Nenets people|Nenets]]. They are also known as Forest Nenets or Forest Yurak because they live in the forest region or [[Taiga]] instead of the [[Tundra]] like the other Nenets.
The Khandeyar speak the [[Forest Nenets language|Forest variety]] of [[Nenets languages|Nenets]].

They reside mainly in the [[Altai Republic]] of the [[Russian Federation]]. According to the 1926 census, 6,335 Kumandins lived within the territory of [[Russia]]. In the 2010 census, the number was only 2,892, but possibly the 1926 census included some related peoples. Some Kumandins, living on the banks of the [[Biya River]], from the [[Kuu]] River downstream, almost to the city of [[Biysk]], and along the lower course of the river [[Katun River]], by 1969 were conflated with the [[ethnic Russian]] population.{{harvp|Potapov|1969|p=21}} ==History== [[Omeljan Pritsak]] claimed that ''kuman-'' in the name of the Kumandins is identical in meaning to the names given to the [[Turkic people]], ''[[Cumans]]''-Kipchaks and ''[[Kipchaks|Polovets]]'' (a Slavic term for [[Cumans]]).Pritsak O., ''"Stammesnamen und Titulaturen der altaischen Volker. Ural-Altaische JahrMcher"'', Bd. 24, 1952, Sect. 1–2, pp. 49–104{{harvp|Potapov|1969|p=58}} However, the ''[[Seok (clan)|seoks]]'' (tribes) of the Kumandins have varying origin myths; L. Potapov proposed that they were originally a federation of peoples from different backgrounds: nomadic [[steppe]] pastoralists (such as the [[Cumans]]), [[taiga]] hunters ([[Chuvash people|Chuvash]]), deer pastoralists ([[Nenets people|Nenets]]), and fishers ([[Tatars]]).{{harvp|Potapov|1969|pp=47, 62, 54, 60}} {{quote|[The] Kumans belonged to the Kuman-Kipchak confederation (Polevetses of the Rus annals, Comans of Byzantine sources, Folban of German annals) [and] during the period from the end of the 800s to 1230s CE spread their political influence in the broad steppes from [[Altai Mountains|Altai]] to [[Crimea]] and [[Danube]]. [[Irtysh]] with its adjoining steppes (at least below the lake [[Lake Zaysan|Zaisan]]) was in the sphere of that confederation. Members of the confederation undoubtedly also were the ancestors of the present Kumandy and Teleuts, which is evidenced by their language that like the language of the [[Siberian Tatars|Tobol-Irtysh]] and [[Baraba Tatars]] belongs to the [[Kipchak languages|Kypchak group]].{{harvp|Potapov|1969|p=59}}}} By the 17th century, the Kumandins lived along the river [[Charysh River|Charysh]], near its confluence with the river [[Ob river|Ob]]. A subsequent relocation to the Altai was driven by their unwillingness to pay ''[[yasak]]'' (financial tribute) to the Russian sovereign.{{harvp|Potapov|1969|pp=56–69}} [[Nikolai Aristov|N. Aristov]] linked the Kumandins – and the [[Chelkans]] – to the ancient Turks, "who in the 6th-8th CC. CE created in [[Central Asia]] a powerful nomadic state, which received ... the name [[Göktürks|Turkic Kaganate]]".Aristov N. A., ''Notes on ethnic composition of Türkic tribes and nations''//Olden Times Alive, 1896, v. 3–4, p. 341{{harvp|Potapov|1969|pp=14, 53}} Potapov regarded the Kumandins as being related anthropologically to the [[Uralic peoples]], and suggested that they were less [[East Asia]]n than the Altaians proper.{{harvp|Potapov|1969|p=19}} This subjective impression has been borne out to an extent by genetic research suggesting that most Kumandin males belong to [[Y-DNA]] haplogroups that are generally found in populations further to the west, such as [[haplogroup R1b|R1b]] (although the Kumandins belong to R1b-M73 rather than R1b-M269, the latter being the subclade to which a majority of Europeans belong) and [[Haplogroup N-M231|N-P43]] (Dulik ''et al.'' Aristov asserted: "The tribal possession So, lying to the north of the Hun country, i. e. from the present [[Mongolia]], should be on the northern side of Altai mountains, for its southern slopes were part of the Hun lands... From that, with sufficient reliability can be concluded that the legendary forefather of the Turks descended from the tribe So that lived in the northern Altai, and that the clan So is a small remainder of that, probably not such a small tribe during prehistoric times". {{Languages of | country = Sri Lanka | image = Beginning of an administrative area.svg | image size = 250px | caption = A road sign in Sinhalese, Tamil and English | official = [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]], [[Tamil language|Tamil]] | foreign = [[English language|English]] | sign = [[Sri Lankan sign languages|multiple sign languages]] }} Several languages are spoken in Sri Lanka within the [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]], [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]] and [[Austronesian Languages|Austronesian]] families. [[Sri Lanka]] accords official status to [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]]. The languages spoken on the island nation are deeply influenced by the languages of neighbouring [[India]], the [[Maldives]] and [[Malaysia]]. [[Arab people|Arab]] settlers and the [[colonialism|colonial powers]] of [[Portugal]], the [[Netherlands]] and [[United Kingdom|Britain]] have also influenced the development of modern languages in Sri Lanka. {{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption =Ethnicity in Sri Lanka (2016){{cite web|url= https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ce.html|title= South Asia ::SRI LANKA|publisher= CIA The World Factbook}} |label1 = [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]] |value1 = 74.9 |color1 = blue |label2 = [[Tamil language|Tamil]] and others |value2 = 25.1 |color2 = orange }} == Languages == As per 2016, the Sinhala language is mostly spoken by the [[Sinhalese people]], who constitute approximately 74.9% of the national population and total about 16.6 million. It uses the [[Sinhalese script|Sinhala abugida]] script, which is derived from the ancient [[Brahmi script]]. The [[Rodiya language]], a dialect of Sinhala, is spoken by the low-[[Indian caste system|caste]] community of chamodi veddhas. The [[Veddah]] people, totaling barely 2,500 in 2002,{{e18|ved|Veddah}} are thought to have once spoken a distinct language, possibly a creolised form of an earlier indigenous language. The Tamil language is spoken by [[Sri Lankan Tamils]], as well as by [[Indian Tamils of Sri Lanka|Tamil migrants]] from the neighboring [[India]]n state of Tamil Nadu and by most [[Sri Lankan Moors]]. Tamil speakers number around 4.7 million. There are more than 50,000 speakers of the [[Sri Lanka Malay|Sri Lankan Creole Malay]] language, which is strongly influenced by the Malay language. == Languages of foreign influence == [[File:Kandy War Grave stripe.JPG|left|thumbnail|English, Sinhala and Tamil languages on a war grave memorial plate in Kandy.
(''click to see full view of memorial plate'')|600px]] English in Sri Lanka is fluently spoken by approximately 10%{{cite web | url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ce.html | title=Sri Lanka – language | accessdate=20 June 2014}} of the population, and widely used for official and commercial purposes. It is the native language of approximately 74,000 people, mainly in urban areas. A handful of the 3,400 [[Burgher people|people of Portuguese descent]] speak [[Sri Lankan Portuguese creole]].{{e18|idb|Indo-Portuguese (Sri Lanka)}} The [[Islam in Sri Lanka|Muslim]] community in Sri Lanka widely uses [[Arabic language|Arabic]] for religious purposes. Seldom used nowadays is [[Arwi]], a written register of Tamil that uses the Arabic script and has extensive lexical influences from Arabic. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140516191826/http://lanintegmin.gov.lk/ Ministry of National Languages and Social Integration, Sri Lanka] *[http://www.languagesdept.gov.lk/ Department of Official Languages, Sri Lanka] *[http://www.ethnologue.com/country/LK/languages Ethnologue report for Sri Lanka] *[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/lktoc.html Sri Lanka Country Studies] {{Languages of Sri Lanka}} {{Languages of South Asia}} [[Category:Languages of Sri Lanka| ]]

'''Leonard Emil Mins''' (? - ?) was an American who worked in the Russian Section of the Research and Analysis Division of the [[Office of Strategic Services]] (OSS) during [[World War II]]. Mins also worked for Soviet Military Intelligence ([[GRU]]).
Mins joined the [[Communist Party of the United States]] (CPUSA) in 1919 and worked for the Communist movement in Germany in 1920 and 1921. In 1924 and 1925 Mins worked for the Executive Committee of the [[Comintern]] as a translator. From 1927 to 1932 Mins did Communist Party work in the [[United States]]. In 1934 he transferred his party membership to the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).
Mins was in [[France]] in 1938 working with exiled German writers, one of whom was the father of the later notorious East German spymaster and [[Stasi]] officer [[Markus Wolf]]. In his 1997 memoirs Wolf recalled his old friend as, "a Communist exile who had been my parents' close friend" in Russia. "He had been the channel through which my father was able to communicate with us during his internment in France."
Mins worked for the OSS from 1942 to late 1943, and worked mostly on a survey of strategic minerals and [[oil reserves]] in Asia and the Soviet Union. Mins was the subject of a [[Dies Committee]] investigation in 1943. Mins denied being a member of the [[Communist Party of the United States]] (CPUSA) but admitted he taught at the Workers School, a Communist controlled entity, and served on the editorial board of ''[[Partisan Review]]'', had been a member of the [[John Reed (journalist)|John Reed Club]], written for the ''[[New Masses]]'', and a member of the League of American Writers. Mins admitted he had lived in Moscow from 1934 to 1936 but insisted he only made translations for the [[Soviet Academy of Sciences]].
==Venona== Leonard Mins cover name in Soviet Military Intelligence, and as deciphered in the [[Venona project]], is "Smith". Mins is referenced in the following [[Venona project]] decrypts:
*1131 GRU New York to Moscow, 12 July 1943 *1348 GRU New York to Moscow, 16 August 1943 *1350 GRU New York to Moscow, 17 August 1943 *1373 GRU New York to Moscow, 23 August 1943 *1456 GRU New York to Moscow, 8 September 1943

The '''Lister Medal''' is an award presented by the [[Royal College of Surgeons of England]] in recognition of contributions to [[surgery|surgical science]]. It is named after the English surgeon [[Joseph Lister, 1st Baron Lister|Joseph Lister]] (1827-1912), whose work on antiseptics established the basis of modern sterile surgery.
The medal has its origins in the Lister Memorial Fund, started by the [[Royal Society]], which was raised by public subscription after Lister's death, with the object of creating a lasting mark of respect to his memory. In 1920, the Royal College of Surgeons of England became the trustees and administrators of the fund. They were entrusted with the task of awarding a monetary prize and a bronze medal (gold since 1984) every three years, irrespective of nationality, to those who had made outstanding contributions to surgical science. The triennial award is decided by a committee representing the Royal Society, the Royal College of Surgeons of England, the [[Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland]], the [[University of Edinburgh]], and the [[University of Glasgow]].
The Lister Medal, although it is not always awarded to a surgeon, is one of the most prestigious honours a surgeon can receive. The obverse of the medal consists of a representation of a bust of Lord Lister. The reverse side has the recipient's name across centre, and around the edge of the medal is text naming the award along with the dedication:
{{cquote|FOR DISTINGUISHED CONTRIBUTIONS TO SURGICAL SCIENCE}}
On the occasion of the award, the medallist delivers the '''Lister Oration''' (sometimes called the "Lister Memorial Lecture"). The first award was announced in 1924, with the presentation and the lecture taking place the following year. The most recent award was made in 2015, with a total of 27 people having received the medal to date.

{{Redirect|Matchanu|the Thai submarine|Matchanu-class submarine}} '''Macchanu''' ({{lang-km|មច្ឆានុ}} - ''Mach-chha-nu''), ({{lang-th|มัจฉานุ}}; {{RTGS|''Matchanu''}}) is son of [[Hanuman]] that appears in the [[Cambodia]]n, [[Thailand|Thai]] and other [[Versions of Ramayana|versions of the Ramayana]].<ref name=z/><ref name=x/><ref name=y/><ref name=a>[http://www.learnnc.org/lp/multimedia/2588 ]</ref><ref name=b>[http://www.learnnc.org/lp/editions/ramayana/1189]</ref>
As per these versions of [[Ramayana]], during one of the battles with [[Ravana]]'s army, Hanuman encounters one powerful opponent, who looked like [[vanara]] from waist-up but had tail of a fish. After a fierce battle, as Hanuman was about to hit the creature with his weapons, a golden star shining in the sky above, reveals by way of [[Akashvani (term)|aakashwani]] that the enemy, whom he is going to harm is his own son born by his union with [[Suvannamaccha]], the [[mermaid]] daughter of Ravana. Hanuman, immediately holds his weapons in mid-air and father-son duo recognize each other.<ref name=a/><ref name=b/>
Another version of story tells, while following [[Ahiravana|Maiyarab]] in order to find [[Rama]] and [[Laxmana]], who have been abducted by Maiyarab and taken to his kingdom in netherworld, Hanuman reaches a pond, where he encounters Macchanu. The fight between them is indecisive, therefore, Hanuman is surprised and asks his opponent, who is he. Macchanu introduces, himself as son of Hanuman and Suvannamaccha and so they finally identify and embrace each other. He tells Hanuman that Maiyarab is his foster father, who had picked him up lying on sea shore, where his mother had left him. Although, he does not want to betray Maiyarab but tells Hanuman through a riddle the entrance to the netherworld lies inside the lotus in the pond he was guarding.<ref name=z>{{cite book|title=The Ramayana and the Malay shadow-play by Amin Sweeney, Vālmīki|year=1972|publisher=Penerbit Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia,|pages=238, 246, 440|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qGrYAAAAMAAJ&q=Macchanu&dq=Macchanu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SdqXUK6mAoP5rQfI9IH4Aw&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBw}}</ref><ref name=x>{{cite book|title=Satya sudhā, a critical evaluation of Dr. Satya Vrat Shastri's creative works by Satya Vrat Varma|year=1991|publisher=Eastern Book Linkers|pages=190, 205, 214|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9vxjAAAAMAAJ&q=Macchanu&dq=Macchanu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SdqXUK6mAoP5rQfI9IH4Aw&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw}}</ref><ref name=y>{{cite book|title=Śrīrāmakīrtimahākāvyam: Thāirāmakathāmāśritya praṇītamabhinavaṃ Saṃskr̥tamahākāvyam by Satyavrat Sastri|year=1990|publisher=Mūlāmala Sacadeva Pratiṣṭhānam|pages=xvi,224, 282|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A6QtAAAAMAAJ&q=Macchanu&dq=Macchanu&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SdqXUK6mAoP5rQfI9IH4Aw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAg}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Suvannamaccha]]- the mother of Macchanu. * [[Makardhwaja]] - the son of Hanuman, as per Indian version of Ramayana, where Hanuman is a celibate.

[[File:Beaufort City Hall ribbon cutting.jpg|thumb|right|Ribbon-cutting ceremonies often involve a comically oversized pair of [[scissors]] good for little else.]] {{about|the formal beginning of a major sports event|the American luxury streetwear brand|Opening Ceremony (brand)}} An '''opening ceremony''', '''grand opening''', or '''ribbon-cutting ceremony''' marks the official opening of a newly-constructed location or the start of an event.<ref name="Adams">[https://books.google.com/books?id=shTNn75df5kC&pg=PA89&dq=%22Grand+openings%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiz-ufN57jNAhVFKWMKHdrrAu0Q6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=%22Grand%20openings%22&f=false ''Streetwise Meeting and Event Planning'']. Grand Openings: Chapter 8. [[Adams Media]]. pp. 89–103.</ref> Opening ceremonies at large events such as the [[Olympic Games]], [[FIFA World Cup]], and the [[Rugby World Cup]] might involve thousands of participants and be watched worldwide.
[[File:Inauguração da média.jpg|thumb|Grand opening of a swimming pool, 1941]] In the case of physical establishments, its grand opening might be preceded by a "soft opening" or "[[soft launch]]" in which the establishment begins to operate with little promotion, to allow testing of operations, procedures, and facilities.

A '''professional conference''' is a meeting of professionals in a given subject or [[profession]], dealing with organizational matters, matters concerning the status of the profession, and scientific or technical developments. It differs from an [[academic conference]] in having broader goals, and usually a much broader attendance. they are normally sponsored by the [[professional society]] in the field, and usually are organized on a national basis.
Some are international, usually organized by federations or groups of the national societies in a subject, such as the conferences held by the [[International Federation of Library Associations]] (IFLA).
Some are local, normally by state, province, or other local sections of a national body.
They are often held annually, or on some other recurring basis. Some of the largest societies hold more than one a year.
Others are held as a one time event, and are usually devoted to a specific topic.
== See also == * [[Academic conference]] * [[:wikt:colloquium|Colloquium]] * [[Congress]] * [[Convention (meeting)]] * [[Event Planning and Production]] * [[Seminar]] * [[Symposium]]
