{{Globalize|date=December 2010}} There are several national systems for rating the quality of [[public library|public libraries]].
==United States== The basic public library statistics (not rankings) are published by the [[National Center for Educational Statistics]]; the most recent version was published in July 2006, using data from fiscal year 2005.<ref>[http://nces.ed.gov/surveys/libraries/site_index.asp Library Statistics program site Index]</ref> As of October 1, 2007, the Institute of Museums and Library Services assumed responsibility for the publication of public library statistics.<ref>[http://harvester.census.gov/imls/pubs/pls/index.asp IMLS Library Statistics - Public Library Publications<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A commercial product, ''Hennen’s American Public Library Ratings Information'' [http://haplr-index.com (HAPLR)], is prepared by Thomas J. Hennen Jr. [http://www.haplr-index.com/ResumeLong.htm], Director of [[Waukesha County Federated Library System]] in Wisconsin. It is published annually in the November edition of [[American Libraries]], and rates over 9,000 [[public library|public libraries]] in the United States based on this data.<ref>Library Statistics Program [http://nces.ed.gov/surveys/libraries/FSCS.asp].</ref> Libraries are ranked on 15 input and output measures with comparisons in broad population categories.
An alternative system [https://web.archive.org/web/20090221072437/http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6629180.html (the LJ Index of Public Library Service)] developed by Keith Curry Lance and Ray Lyons, was introduced in the June 15th 2008 issue of [[Library Journal]]. Libraries are rated on four equally weighted per-capita statistics with comparison groups based on total operating expenditures. The four statistics, library visits, circulation, program attendance, and public internet computer uses, were chosen based on correlation analysis. The system awards 5-star, 4-star, and 3-star designations rather than library ranks, due to recognized imprecision of the library statistical data. The LJ Index measures how the levels of services a library provides compares with other libraries. Creators of the LJ Index stress the fact that it does not measure service quality, operational excellence, library effectiveness, nor the degree to which a library meets existing community information needs.
===Controversy=== The HAPLR ratings have drawn significant criticism and praise from members of the library community.
In [[Library Journal]], Oregon State Librarian Jim Scheppke notes that the statistics that HAPLR relies on are misleading because they rely too much on output measures, such as circulation, funding, etc. and not on input measures, such as open hours and patron satisfaction. He adds "To give HAPLR some credit, collectively, the libraries in the top half of the list are definitely better than the libraries in the bottom half, but when it gets down to individual cases, which is what HAPLR claims to be able to do, it doesn't work." <ref>Scheppke, Jim. (1999-11-15) “The Trouble with Hennen”, ''Library Journal'' 124 (19): p. 36, {{ISSN|0363-0277}}</ref>
However, John Berry III, in a Library Journal editorial said "Unfortunately, when you or your library receives any kind of honor, it stimulates the flow of competitive hormones in your professional colleagues. This jealousy rears its ugly head in many ways. We've suffered endless tutorials on the defects in Hennen's rankings. So what? They work!" <ref>[http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA158847.html?q=hennen+1999 April 15, 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607121337/http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA158847.html?q=hennen+1999 |date=June 7, 2011 }} Library Journal</ref>
In a 2008 article in [[Public Libraries]] Ray Lyons and Neal Kaske argue for greater recognition of the strengths and limitations of ratings.<ref>"Honorable Mention: What Public Library National Ratings Say" (Nov/Dec 2008)''Public Libraries'' p.36-41.</ref> They point out that, among other factors, imprecision in library statistics make ratings scores quite approximate, a fact rarely acknowledged by libraries receiving high ratings. The authors also note that HAPLR calculations perform invalid mathematical operations using ordinal rankings, making comparisons of scores between libraries and between years meaningless.
A 2006 Library School Student Writing Award article questions HAPLR’s weighting of factors, and its failure to account for local factors (such as a library’s mission) in measuring a library’s success, the index’s failure to measure computer and Internet usage, and its lack of focus of on newer methods of evaluation, such as customer satisfaction or return on investment.<ref>Nelson, Elizabeth. (Winter 2007) “Library Statistics and the HAPLR Index” by Elizabeth Nelson ''Library Administration & Management'' 21 (1) : p. 9, {{ISSN|0888-4463}}</ref>
Keith Curry Lance and Marti Cox, both of the ''Library Research Service'', take issue with HAPLR’s reasoning backwards from statistics to conclusion, point out the redundancy of HAPLR’s statistical categories, and question its arbitrary system of weighting criteria.<ref>Lance, Keith Curry and Marti A. Cox. (June/July 2000), “Lies, Damn Lies, and Indexes”, ''American Libraries'' 31 (6): p. 82, {{ISSN|0002-9769}}</ref>
Hennen responded to Lance and Cox in the same issue of [[American Libraries]],saying their "thesis seems to be that the job of comparing libraries cannot be done, so I am at fault for having tried. Somehow, unique among American public or private institutions, libraries are just too varied and too local to be compared. Yet despite these assertions, the authors urge individuals to use the NCES Public Library Peer Comparison tool (nces.ed.gov/surveys/libraries/publicpeer/) to do this impossible task." <ref>American Libraries; Jun/Jul2000, Vol. 31 Issue 6, p87, 1p</ref>
==Australia and New Zealand== There is some interest in developing an index in Australia and New Zealand<ref>Alan Bundy in ''APLIS, the Australasian Public Library and Information Science'' {{cite web |url=http://conferences.alia.org.au/alia2000/proceedings/alan.bundy.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070907041145/http://conferences.alia.org.au/alia2000/proceedings/alan.bundy.html |archivedate=2007-09-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Great Britain== Great Britain adopted national standards, and in 2000 the Audit Commission began publishing both a summary annual reports of library conditions and individualized ratings of libraries. Audit Commission personnel base the reports on statistical data, long-range plans, local government commitment to the library, and a site visit. The Audit Commission is an independent body. Every library is assigned a score.<ref>[http://www.bestvalueinspections.gov.uk/ Audit Commission - homepage<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051123124210/http://www.bestvalueinspections.gov.uk/ |date=2005-11-23 }}</ref>
==Germany==
Bertelsmann Publishing partners with the German library association to produce BIX, a library index quite similar to HAPLR. The main difference between BIX and HAPLR, is that BIX was designed to provide comparisons of one library to another in a given year as well as over time. HAPLR compares all libraries to one another only during a given year.<ref>[http://www.bertelsmann-stiftung.de/documents/Projekt_Info_Englisch_010112.pdf English version]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== See also == * [[International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions]] * [[Library computer system]]

{{Italic title}} {{infobox book | | name = Real Marriage: The Truth About Sex, Friendship, and Life Together | title_orig = | translator = | image = RealMarriageDriscoll.jpg | caption = First edition hardcover | author = [[Mark Driscoll (pastor)|Mark Driscoll]],
Grace Driscoll | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = Christian Life | publisher = [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]] | release_date = January 3, 2012 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[e-book]]) | pages = 272 pp (first edition, hardback) | isbn = 140020383X | isbn_note = (first edition, hardback) | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Real Marriage: The Truth About Sex, Friendship, and Life Together''''' is a 2012 marriage book written by [[Christian]] author [[Mark Driscoll (pastor)|Mark Driscoll]] and his wife, Grace, and published by [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]]. The book spent one week on the [[New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]] for advice books,[https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2012-01-22/hardcover-advice/list.html NYT Bestseller list] NY Times however, controversy arose when it was later reported that a former pastor of [[Mars Hill Church]] had contracted with the marketing firm [[Result Source]] to affect metrics on the best-seller list shortly before resigning. The church also created a Real Marriage sermon series based on the book.{{cite web|url=https://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage|title=Real Marriage series}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Content== In the preface, Mark and Grace Driscoll state that they developed the book after they had counseled many couples—many of them facing challenges on how to apply the Bible to their marriage. According to the authors, many of the couples they counseled were afraid of asking questions, and the book sought to address those questions.Driscoll, ''Real Marriage'', p 5-25. The book holds to the [[complementarianism|complementarian]] view of marriage between one man and one woman. The book is divided into three parts: Marriage, Sex, and The Last Day. In part one, the Driscolls share their personal stories, including their individual upbringings, their years as a dating couple, and conflict in their marriage. In part two, the authors deal with three different views of sex—sex as god, sex as gross, and sex as gift. In part three, the authors lay out how to "reverse engineer" one's marriage, by examining how to "finish well" on its last day. ==Real Marriage Series== The book was later turned into a sermon series, featuring Mark Driscoll and his wife Grace, with question and answers at the end of each sermon. Paralleling the book's content, the series is divided into: *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/new-marriage-same-spouse "New Marriage Same Spouse"] *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/friend-with-benefits "Friend with Benefits"] Driscoll cites the story of [[Martin Luther]] and [[Katharina von Bora]] to discuss friendship in the context of marriage.{{cite web|url=https://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/friends-with-benefits|title=Real Marriage series}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/men-and-marriage "Men and Marriage"] Driscoll cites the [[book of Genesis]], stating that when Eve sinned, God called on Adam, not Eve. Driscoll states that men are responsible for their wife and family.{{cite web|url=https://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/men-and-marriage|title=Real Marriage series}} *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/the-respectful-wife "The Respectful Wife"] Driscoll states that this chapter was written by his wife Grace, and that he is "just delivering the mail." Driscoll refers to the book of [[Ephesians]] stating that a "respectful wife" consists of praying for her husband, "respecting him thereby making him respectable," but not enabling him with silent compliance.{{cite web|url=https://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/the-respectful-wife|title=Real Marriage series}} *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/taking-out-the-trash "Taking Out the Trash"] *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/sex-god-gross-or-gift "Sex: God, Gross, or Gift?"] *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/disgrace-and-grace "Disgrace and Grace"] *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/the-porn-path "The Porn Path"] Mark and Grace Driscoll invite a former employee of the porn industry to discuss her life and experience from that line of work.{{cite web|url=https://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/the-porn-path|title=Real Marriage series}} *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/selfish-lovers-and-servant-lovers "Selfish Lovers and Servant Lovers"] *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/can-we-________ "Can We________"] *[http://markdriscoll.org/sermons/real-marriage/reverse-engineering-your-life-and-marriage "Reverse-Engineering Your Life and Marriage"] ==Reception== Critical reception for the book has been mixed, with [[Publishers Weekly]] praising the book's "boldly refreshing approach".[http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-4002-0383-3 Nonfiction Review: Real Marriage] Publishers Weekly [[Relevant (magazine)|Relevant]] wrote that "Though it's certainly not all bad, the helpful and the harmful in Real Marriage are too thoroughly intertwined to be helpful."[http://www.relevantmagazine.com/culture/books/reviews/27795-review-real-marriage REVIEW: Real Marriage] Relevant Magazine ===Criticism=== The book has faced criticism due to the Driscolls' detailed and frank discussion of sex in ''Real Marriage''.[http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2012/01/06/pastors-detailed-book-on-sex-divides-reviewers-sparks-controversy/ Pastor’s detailed book on sex divides reviewers, sparks controversy] CNN The Driscolls have stated that they did not write the book for people looking to read the book for "voyeuristic" intents, but because they viewed sex as an important part of marriage and that the majority of marriage help books were written for people who had not "experienced sexual assault or been abused or exposed to pornography or sexual sins".[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/book-news/religion/article/49954-mark-and-grace-driscoll-telling-the-truth-about-marriage.html Mark and Grace Driscoll: Telling the Truth about Marriage] Publishers Weekly The book has also been criticized for content such as chapters entitled "The Respectful Wife", with critics stating that the book was "an astoundingly unbelievable work of disrespect for women"[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/01/13/mark-driscoll-s-sex-manual-real-marriage-scandalizes-evangelicals.html Mark Driscoll’s Sex Manual ‘Real Marriage’ Scandalizes Evangelicals] The Daily Beast and that "the book focuses so much on sex that it can create the impression that it's the most important element of marriage".[http://www.christianpost.com/news/mark-driscoll-talks-real-marriage-with-cnns-piers-morgan-71255/ Mark Driscoll Talks 'Real Marriage' With CNN's Piers Morgan] Christian Post Mark Driscoll has replied to these criticisms, stating that he was aware that the book's content would "catch flak" and that "accommodating everyone would be impossible".[http://www.christianpost.com/news/mark-driscoll-responds-to-criticism-of-church-and-sex-in-real-talk-67827/ Mark Driscoll Responds to Criticism of Sex Talk in 'Real Marriage'] Christian Post ==New York Times Bestseller controversy== In March 2014, ''The Los Angeles Times'' reported that Mars Hill Church contracted with [[Result Source]] "to conduct a bestseller campaign for your book, 'Real Marriage' on the week of January 2, 2012. The bestseller campaign is intended to place 'Real Marriage' on the New York Times bestseller list for the Advice How-to list." To achieve this, the contract stated that "RSI will be purchasing at least 11,000 total orders in one-week." This took place and as a result, the book was successfully ranked #1 on the hardcover advice bestseller list on January 22, 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-pastor-contract-resultsource-bestseller-lists-20140305,0,7039368.story#axzz2vCwCm0fo |title=Can bestseller lists be bought? |work=[[LA Times]] |author=Carolyn Kellogg |date=March 6, 2014 |accessdate=March 7, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mhpbooks.com/got-200000-congratulations-youre-a-bestselling-author/ |title=Got $200,000? Congratulations, you’re a bestselling author. |publisher=[[Melville House Publishing]] |author=Julia Fleischaker |date=March 7, 2014 |accessdate=March 7, 2014}} On March 28, 2015, a former elder of the church revealed that [[Mark Driscoll]] had not been involved in initiating nor signing the contract with the marketing firm Result Source. The elder stated that the business relationship with Result Source was initiated by a pastor who resigned shortly thereafter, and remaining church leaders disagreed over the completion of the contract stating that it would reflect badly on the church and Mark Driscoll.{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/article/former.mars.hill.elder.gives.inside.story.of.controversy.plan.to.boost.mark.driscolls.book.sales/52667.htm |title=Former Mars Hill elder gives inside story of controversial plan to boost Mark Driscoll's book sales}} == See also == * [[Mars Hill Church]] * [[Acts 29 Network]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Real Marriage}} [[Category:2012 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Books about Christianity]] [[Category:Self-help books]] [[Category:Thomas Nelson (publisher) books]] [[Category:Marriage]]

The '''Rer Bare''' (or '''Rerebere''', '''Adona''') are a tribe in [[Ethiopia]]'s eastern [[Ogaden]] region on the [[Shabele River]], near [[Somalia]], who currently speak [[Somali language|Somali]]. They appear to have shifted to Somali from a now-extinct language.<ref>{{E18|rer|Rer Bare language}}</ref>
== Language and origins == Their unattested but apparently non-Somali language<ref>{{glottolog|rerb1235|Rer Bare}}</ref> seems to have been first mentioned in print by [[Lionel Bender (linguist)|Lionel Bender]] in 1975:
: D. W. Mcclure, Sr. first reported to me the presence of [[Sudan]]ese [[immigrant]]s on the Wabi Shebelle River at [[Gode]] in the eastern Ogaden. They are said to have their own language, bearing the given name [Rerebere]. Later Taye Reya informed me that Sudanese immigrants are found along the [[Ganale River|Ganale]] and [[Dawa River]]s as well, and that they are referred to by the [[Somali people|Somali]] as ''rer bare'' (''rer'' means sub-[[tribe]] in Somali.) They are also known as ''adona'', and they speak Somali as well as their own language... I cannot say with certainty whether they speak one or more languages of what any of them is... So far no linguistic data has come my way.
Others have linked the Rer Bare to the [[Bantu languages|Bantu language family]], implying that they may be the remnants of a Bantu-speaking pre-Somali population or, like the "[[Somali Bantu]]" in the [[Jubba River]] valley of southern [[Somalia]], the descendants of Bantu slaves imported from other parts of East Africa in the 19th century. Tobias Hagmann refers to them as "Somalised Bantu".<ref name=HAGM>Hagmann, Tobias (2005): [http://www.tobiashagmann.net/documents/Hagmann_2005_ROAPE.pdf Challenges of decentralisation in Ethiopia's Somali Region], Briefing for Review of African Political Economy Vol. 32, No. 103, p. 5</ref> According to [[Ulrich Braukämper]]:
: The Adonē, a dark-skinned Somali-speaking population on the banks of the Wabi Shäbälle, are obviously the offspring of Bantu slaves who settled and expanded there since the 19th century.<ref>Braukämper, Ulrich (2003): ''Islamic History and Culture in Southern Ethiopia. Collected Essays'', ''Göttinger Studien zur Ethnologie'' 9, {{ISBN|978-3-8258-5671-7}} (p. 15, 137)</ref>
A British hunter, Colonel Swayne, who visited [[Imi, Ethiopia|Imi]] in February 1893, relates that he was the guest of Gabba Oboho, a chief of the Adona, for several days.<ref>H. G. C. Swayne, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1773666 "A Trip to Harar and Imé", ''Geographical Journal''], 2 (September 1893), p. 251</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Samuel Simon Krafsur | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = January 10, 1913 | birth_place = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | death_date = June 1983 | death_place = [[St. Petersburg, Florida]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = [[Communist Party of America]]
[[Abraham Lincoln Brigade]] | education = [[Northeastern University (Boston, Massachusetts)|Northeastern University]] | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Samuel Simon Krafsur''' (January 10, 1913 – June 1983) was a [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]]-born [[journalist]] who worked for the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] news agency [[TASS (USSR)|TASS]] during [[World War II]]. He was also known as '''Bill Krafsur'''. ==Biography== Krafsur was mentioned in the [[Venona]] intercepts under the codename IDE. He was used by the [[KGB]] during the war as a source of information and for recruiting journalists as informants and agents, and is referred to in the [[NSA]] archives as a "KGB agent"{{ref|NSA|1}} [http://www.nsa.gov/venona/venon00116.cfm?CFID=2412771&CFTOKEN=59316524&jsessionid=c830b21ad087a$5FoV$B#17]. In the 1930s Krafsur joined the [[Communist Party of America]]. He attended [[Northeastern University (Boston, Massachusetts)|Northeastern University]] for a year. He lived at 68 Phillips Street in Boston before going to [[Spain]] to fight with the [[Abraham Lincoln Brigade]] during the [[Spanish Civil War]], where he was wounded in 1937. In 1938 Krafsur was a member of the editorial staff of "The Volunteers for Liberty" a newspaper which was an, "organ of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade" organization out of 125 West 45 Street in [[New York City]]. In April 1938 he was in charge of finding veterans to tell their war stories to be made into radio plays written by [[Irwin Shaw]]. He began working for TASS in 1941 after being recruited by the Soviet agent [[Vladimir Pravdin]]. He became the assistant to the manager [[Laurence Todd]] at the Washington sub-bureau.The Two Faces of TASS, Theodore Eduard Kruglak, page 99. Krafsur was considered an important asset to the KGB because of the many contacts he had with other newsmen. He was the deputy TASS bureau chief in [[Washington, D.C.]] and the [[FBI]] spent a lot of time and effort trying to identify who he was under his codename IDE. In May 1944, he was described in a KGB cable from New York to Moscow as, "absolutely devoted to the [[USSR]]." He provided at least twenty leads of people for possible recruitment including [[Josef Berger (speechwriter)|Joseph Berger]], a personal aide to the chairman of the [[Democratic National Committee]], and [[I. F. Stone]]. In 1949, Laurence Todd was relieved of his managing duties and instead given the title of senior correspondent. In this same year Krafsur left TASS and was later called before the [[House Committee on Un-American Activities]] where he chose not to cooperate. Later he worked in a toy store. In the early 1960s he married the ex-wife of the secretary-treasurer of the [[Mine, Mill, and Smelters Union]]. He died, at the age of seventy, in [[St. Petersburg, Florida]] in 1983 under the name "Samuel Krafsur". ==Note== *{{note|NSA|1}} National Security Agency Archives [http://permanent.access.gpo.gov/lps33230/www.nsa.gov/docs/venona/monographs/monograph-1.html], National Cryptological Museum, [http://www.nsa.gov/museum/museu00040.cfm] Custodian of documents for the Army Signals Intelligence Corp == Sources == * {{cite book|ref=harv|author1=John Earl Haynes|author2=Harvey Klehr|title=Venona: Decoding Soviet Espionage in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M8p00bTFvRkC&lpg=PA243&pg=PA243#v=onepage&q=%22Venona%20makes%20clear%20that%20Krafsur%20was%20an%20important%20Soviet%20agent%22|accessdate=23 Sep 2018|year=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-12987-8|pages=242–244, 248}} * {{cite book|author=Nigel West|title=MORTAL CRIMES — The Greatest Theft in History: The Soviet Penetration of the Manhattan Project|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4TRKAAAAQBAJ|accessdate=24 Sep 2018|year=2013|publisher=Enigma Books|isbn=978-1-929631-29-2}} * Social Security Death Index, USA. == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070331010314/http://www.theworldintelligencereview.com/books%26culture/archives/2005/03/spying_on_ameri.html Spying on America] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Krafsur, Samuel}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:20th-century American journalists]] [[Category:Northeastern University alumni]] [[Category:Espionage in the United States]] [[Category:Writers from Boston]] [[Category:Writers from St. Petersburg, Florida]] [[Category:Abraham Lincoln Brigade members]] [[Category:American communists]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:American spies for the Soviet Union]] [[Category:American people in the Venona papers]] [[Category:20th-century American writers]]

{{Ethnic group |group=Soussi (Isussin)
Shlḥi |population=~5.1 million (14.2% of Morocco) |popplace=[[Morocco]]-[[Atlas Mountains]], [[Sous|Sous Valley]] |langs=[[Shilha language|Shilha]] |rels=Predominantly [[Muslim]] |related=[[Berbers]] }} The '''Soussi people''', also called '''Isussin''' or '''Swassa''', are a major [[Berbers|Berber]] subgroup primarily inhabiting the southwestern mountains, [[Sous River]], and southern coastal regions of [[Morocco]].{{cite book|author=Wolfgang Weissleder|title=The Nomadic Alternative: Modes and Models of Interaction in the African-Asian Deserts and Steppes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JRyqfpi5BKcC |year=1978|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-081023-3|pages=11–12}}''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' 2008, [http://www.britannica.com/eb/topic-541262/Shluh Shluh]. ==Overview== [[File:Imilchil Weddings.jpg|thumb|A Soussi Berber woman at a traditional wedding.]] The Soussis traditionally call themselves ''Isoussin''. This endonym is rendered as les ''Soussis'' in French.{{cite book|last1=Dalby|first1=Andrew|title=Dictionary of Languages: The definitive reference to more than 400 languages|date=2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=1408102145|page=614|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=7dHNCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA614#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2 November 2016}} The Soussis are also known as ''Isoussin'' and ''Swassa''. Among Arabic speakers, ''Chleuh'' serves as an appellation for Berbers generally, although ''Amazigh''/''Imazighin'' is the proper Berber self-name for Berbers as a whole.{{cite book|author=John A. Shoup|title=Ethnic Groups of Africa and the Middle East: An Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SPBfnT_E1mgC |year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-362-0|pages=53–54}} The Soussi people live mainly in [[Morocco]]'s southern Atlantic coast, the High [[Atlas Mountains]], the [[Anti Atlas]] mountains, and the [[Sous]] Valley. They are of [[Berbers|Berber]] origin, which along with the Berber people, includes other ethnic subgroups such as the Tuareg, Rif, Kabyle, Shawia and Beraber.{{cite book|author=Marian Aguiar|editor=Anthony Appiah and Henry Louis Gates|title=Encyclopedia of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A0XNvklcqbwC |year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-533770-9|page=175}} The Soussi people are a part of Morocco's Berber-speaking community, and the southernmost residing Berber population.{{cite book|author=James Stuart Olson|title=The Peoples of Africa: An Ethnohistorical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MdaAdBC-_S4C |year=1996|publisher=Greenwood |isbn=978-0-313-27918-8|page=91}}{{cite book|author=Marian Aguiar|editor=Anthony Appiah and Henry Louis Gates|title=Encyclopedia of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A0XNvklcqbwC |year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-533770-9|pages=106-107}} ==History== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Zilveren hoofdversiering TMnr 6388-1.jpg|thumb|A traditional Shilha dowry item]] In antiquity, Berbers traded with the [[Phoenicia]]ns and [[Punics|Carthaginians]] in commercial entrepots and colonies along the northwestern littoral. They established the ancient kingdom of [[Mauretania]], which fell under [[Roman Empire|Roman]] rule in 33 CE, before eventually being reunited under Berber sovereignty.{{cite book|author=James B. Minahan|title=Encyclopedia of Stateless Nations: Ethnic and National Groups around the World, 2nd Edition|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=pGClDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA379#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2016|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-61069-954-9|pages=378–379}} During the 7th century, the Islamic [[Umayyad Caliphate]] invaded the Berber and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] strongholds in the Northwest Africa, seizing [[Carthage]] in 698 AD. Although the Umayyads nominally controlled Morocco over the following years, their rule was tenuous due to Berber resistance, shortly in 739 AD Umayyad Arabs were killed by the Moroccan Berbers at the battle of Nobles and Bagdoura. Morocco remained under the rule of Berber kingdoms such as [[Barghawata]] and [[Banu Midrar|Midrar]] .. etc. In 789 AD, with the approval of the locals, a former Umayyad courtier established the [[Idrisid dynasty]] that ruled in Fez. It lasted until 970 AD, as various petty states vied for control over the ensuing centuries. After 1053, Morocco was ruled by a succession of Muslim dynasties founded by Berber tribes. Among these were the [[Almoravid dynasty]] (1053-1147) who spread Islam in Morocco, the [[Almohad dynasty]] (1147-1275), and the [[Marinid dynasty]] (1213-1524). In 1668, a sharifan family from the east assumed control and established the incumbent [[Alaouite dynasty|Alawite dynasty]].{{cite book|author=Syed Farid Alatas|title=Applying Ibn Khaldūn: The Recovery of a Lost Tradition in Sociology|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=0aLAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1317594002|page=82}} Although the Soussis gradually adopted Islam, they and other Berbers in the mountains have held on to their traditional language, culture and [[traditional Berber religion|religious customs]] to varying degrees.{{cite book|author=Douglas Porch|title=The Conquest of Morocco|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R2N3JzfsfHkC&pg=PA7|year=2005|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-1-4299-9885-7|page=7}}{{cite book|author=[[:fr:Robert Montagne|Robert Montagne]]|year= 1963|title= Les Berbères et le makhzen dans le sud du Maroc; essai sur la transformation politique des Berbères sédentaires (groupe chleuh)| publisher= Paris: F. Alcan|language=French|oclc= 1949564}} A small minority of the Shilha people are Christians and Jewish. The French and Spanish colonial empires partitioned Morocco in 1904, and the southern part of the territory was declared a French protectorate in 1912. Arabization remained an official state policy under both the colonial and succeeding post-independence governments. With the spread of the [[Berber Spring]] to Berber territory during the 1980s, the Berbers sought to reaffirm their Berber roots. This culminated with a proposal by Berber nationalists in 2013 to establish an independent Sousse state within a greater Morocco federation. ==Society== [[File:A family from the Chleuh Shilha Shluh ethnic sub-group, Berber Morocco.jpg|thumb|A Shilha family]] The Soussis mainly live in Morocco's Atlas Mountains and [[Sous]] Valley. Traditionally, they are farmers who also keep herds.{{cite book|author=James Stuart Olson|authorlink= James S. Olson|title=The Peoples of Africa: An Ethnohistorical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MdaAdBC-_S4C |year=1996|publisher=Greenwood |isbn=978-0-313-27918-8|page=523}} Some are semi-nomadic, growing crops during the season when water is available, and moving with their herds during the dry season. The Soussi communities in the southwestern mountains of Morocco cooperated with each other in terms of providing reciprocal grazing rights as seasons changed, as well as during periods of war. These alliances were re-affirmed by annual festive gatherings, where one Soussi community would invite nearby and distant Shilha communities.{{cite book|author=George Peter Murdock|title=Culture and Society: Twenty-Four Essays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MvrZVQ-rud8C&pg=PA343|date=15 October 1965|publisher=University of Pittsburgh Press|isbn=978-0-8229-7406-2|pages=343–344}} ==Language== The Soussis speak the [[Shilha language|Tasoussit language]], a Tasoussit dialect. It belongs to the [[Berber languages|Berber]] branch of the [[Afroasiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]] family.[https://www.ethnologue.com/language/shi Tachelhit], Ethnologue (2007) Their language is sometimes referred to as ''Sous-Berber''.{{cite book|author=Maarten Kossmann|title=The Arabic Influence on Northern Berber|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Se-BAAAAQBAJ |year=2013|publisher=BRILL Academic|isbn=978-90-04-25309-4|pages=19-20}}{{cite book|author1=MG Kossmann|author2=HJ Stroomer|editor=Alan S. Kaye|title=Phonologies of Asia and Africa: Including the Caucasus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T6jmziooEk0C |year=1997|publisher=Eisenbrauns|isbn=978-1-57506-019-4|pages=461–462}} As of 2014, there were around 5 million Shilha speakers, constituting 14.1% of the Moroccan population.{{cite web|last1=Haut commissariat au Plan, Moroccan Kingdom|first1=Haut commissariat au Plan|title=Recensement général de la Maroc|url=http://rgphentableaux.hcp.ma/Default1/|website=HCP|publisher=Haut commissariat du Plan|accessdate=16 August 2016|language=Franch}} The Soussi language differs considerably from certain Berber varieties, such as those spoken by the Tuareg.Joseph R. Applegate (1957), [https://www.jstor.org/stable/4322927 Berber Studies I: Shilha], Middle East Journal, Vol. 11, No. 3 (Summer, 1957), pages 324-327 ==See also== *[[High Atlas]] ==Further reading== *"Shluh", ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]] online'', 2008, webpage: [http://www.britannica.com/eb/topic-541262/Shluh EB-Shluh]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.muturzikin.com/cartesafrique/29.htm Maroc - Carte linguistique] {{Ethnic groups in Morocco}} {{Berber}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Berber peoples and tribes]] [[Category:Berbers in Morocco]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Morocco]]

The '''Sichuan Mongols''' are officially counted among the [[Mongols in China|Mongolian nationality in China]]. However, they are a distinct ethno-linguistic group from all other [[Mongolian people]]s. They call themselves Mongols and possess their own clothing, history and language. All other peoples in the region recognize them as Mongols (''Mengzu'').
The Sichuan Mongols' main religion is [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. A sizable temple remains in active use just behind the prince's house. Most temples and altars being destroyed during the [[Cultural Revolution]] but many of them were recovered afterwards. Most Sichuan Mongols are farmers or fishermen, leading quiet lives in their remote villages. They observe [[Buddhist festival]]s.
Historically, the Mongols in [[Yongning, Sichuan|Yongning]] were ruled by three chiefs, elevated to power by [[Kublai Khan]] in the 13th century. Before Communist rule, the Mongol monarch acted as a warlord over the whole region. When the [[Communists]] took over, they deposed him, not killing him so as not to make him a martyr in the people's eyes. The Mongol palace was destroyed and the prince was sent to a reeducation camp for several years. The prince, La Ping Chu, is still alive today and respected by his people, although he is not allowed to rule. Many older Mongols still bow their heads in respect when they pass him on the street.

[[File:Clare College, Cambridge, July 2010 (16).JPG|thumb|Clare College, University of Cambridge a regular venue for the Social Stratification Seminars.]] The '''Social Stratification Research Seminar (UK)''' is an annual research colloquium for original, empirically informed [[Sociology|sociological]] presentations on [[social stratification]]. The Social Stratification Research Seminars have been running almost every autumn since 1968. The seminars have mainly been hosted at the [[University of Cambridge]] and were often organised by the [https://research.sociology.cam.ac.uk/social-science-research-group Social Science Research Group (formerly the Sociological Research Group)]. The seminars have also been held at the [[Cardiff University|University of Cardiff (]]2003-5), the [[University of Edinburgh]] (2014, 2017), the [[University of Milan]] (2015), the [[University of Stirling]] (2007, 2011) and [[Utrecht University]] (2010).<ref>http://www.camsis.stir.ac.uk/stratif/conf_archive.html</ref>
The original movers and shakers behind the seminar were three distinguished British scholars working in the field of social stratification - [https://research.sociology.cam.ac.uk/profile/professor-robert-martin-bob-blackburn Professor Robert (Bob) Blackburn], [https://www.fitz.cam.ac.uk/about/people/fellows-profiles/professor-ken-prandy Professor Ken Prandy,] and Professor Alexander (Sandy) Stewart. Since the early part of this [[Year 2000|millennium]] the seminar has been organised by [https://www.stir.ac.uk/people/255764 Professor Paul Lambert], who is Professor of Sociology at the [[University of Stirling]] and a longstanding fan of [[Stirling Albion F.C.|Stirling Albion F.C]]. The annual call for papers is usually issued in the spring and the seminar is usually held on two consecutive days in the early September. Proposals for papers for presentations are invited from any area of research into social stratification and social inequality. The organizers do not usually limit the number of delegates attending. There are no parallel sessions and therefore there is an upper limit on the number of paper presentations that can be accommodated.
A salient feature of the Social Stratification Research Seminars has been how to appropriately measure social stratification in contemporary societies. An approach that has been developed by researchers who are regular contributors to the seminars are Social Interaction and Stratification Scales.<ref>See Stewart, A., PRANDY, K. and Blackburn, R.M., 1973. Measuring the class structure. ''Nature'', ''245''(5426), p.415.</ref> This approach is the foundation of the [http://www.camsis.stir.ac.uk/ CAMSIS Project] which is an internationally comparative assessment of the structures of social interaction and stratification across a number of countries.
A number of prominent research publications contain work that was developed and showcased at the seminars. These works include an edited volume entitled [https://www.routledge.com/Social-Stratification-Trends-and-Processes/Connelly-Gayle-Lambert/p/book/9781409430964 ''Social stratification:Trends and processes'']<ref>Lambert, P., Connelly, M.R., Blackburn, R.M. and Gayle, V. eds., 2013. ''Social stratification: Trends and processes''. Ashgate Publishing, Ltd..</ref>'','' and special issues of the journal ''[https://rsa.tandfonline.com/toc/rsoc21/11/2-3?nav=tocList Contemporary Social Science]'' and the [https://www.emeraldinsight.com/toc/ijssp/28/7%2F8 ''International Journal of Sociology and Social Policy''] [https://www.emeraldinsight.com/toc/ijssp/28/5%2F6].
Notable sociological scholars in the field of social stratification who have attended the Social Stratification Research Seminars include [https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?hl=en&user=-abxxmUAAAAJ&view_op=list_works&sortby=pubdate Professor Harry Ganzeboom], [https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?user=gscMj2wAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=sra Dr Wendy Bottero], [https://www.ncl.ac.uk/gps/staff/profile/geoffpayne.html#publications Professor Geoff Payne], [https://www.unibas.ch/en/University/Administration-Services/The-President-s-Office/Institutional-Development/Sustainability/Research/Social-Sciences.html Professor Max Bergman], and [http://www.lse.ac.uk/researchAndExpertise/Experts/profile.aspx?KeyValue=l.platt@lse.ac.uk Professor Lucinda Platt]. The meeting is also attended by early career researchers such as [https://www.stir.ac.uk/people/266076 Jennifer Ferguson].

The '''Solzhenitsyn Aid Fund''' (officially '''Russian Public Fund to Aid Political Prisoners and their Families''', also '''Fund for the Aid of Political Prisoners''', '''Public Aid Fund''') was a charity foundation and support network set up by [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]] and [[Alexander Ginzburg]] that distributed funds and material support to [[Political prisoner|political]] and religious prisoners across the [[Soviet Union]] throughout the 1970s and 1980s.
== Founding ==
The fund was formed on the initiative of writer and [[political prisoner]] Alexander Ginzburg. Families of arrested [[Soviet dissidents|dissidents]] often suffered repercussions such as the loss of jobs and opportunities to study. During his time in [[labor camp]]s, Ginzburg managed to coordinate relatives and friends to help other inmates and their families. This included support such as donating household goods for those in exile, helping relatives who faced expulsion from work, or offering places to stay in Moscow for wives who journeyed to visit their husbands in remote Siberian camps.
After his release in 1972, Ginzburg consulted with Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn on how to continue this informal support. Solzhenitsyn offered a quarter of his [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize]] award for the cause. After Solzhenitsyn was expelled from the USSR in 1974 following the publication of ''[[The Gulag Archipelago]]'', he set up a fund in Switzerland, donating all present and future international royalties for the book to it. The funds were from then on brought into the USSR and distributed through a network of volunteers.<ref name="kifa">{{Cite journal|url = http://gazetakifa.ru/content/view/295/|title = Делай то, что без тебя сделано не будет. Н.Д.Солженицына рассказывает об истории и сегодняшнем дне Солженицынского фонда|last = |first = |date = 2004-04-28|journal = КИФА|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 2015-08-10|issue = 4 (19)}}</ref>
== Activities == A first goal of the fund was to help [[gulag]] inmates and their families to survive. For this, groups of people, unknown to one another, collected information on the existence and whereabouts of political prisoners across the Soviet Union and distributed funds and other material support to them and their families. Other charitable organizations, such as Christian Orthodox organizations that collected clothing and other items, passed those donations onto the Aid Fund for redistribution. The Aid Fund also contributed funds for the support of political prisoners who were sent to [[Political abuse of psychiatry in the Soviet Union|psychiatric imprisonment]]. It paid for the travel expenses of those who traveled to distant trials to support the political dissenters.<ref name=walker-altruism>{{Cite book| isbn = 9781137289834| pages = 180–203| last1 = Lim| first1 = Jie-Hyun| last2 = Walker| first2 = Barbara| last3 = Lambert| first3 = Peter| last4 = Walker, Barbara| title = Mass Dictatorship and Memory as Ever Present Past| chapter = Accomplices of Violence: Guilt and Purification through Altruism among the Moscow Human Rights Activists of the 1960s and 1970s| date = 2014}}</ref>{{rp|189}} A second goal of the fund was the support of cultural initiatives, such as a series of memoirs of emigrants.<ref name="kifa" />
The administrators of the fund ensured that the money was sent legally to banks in Moscow; after the state had taken one third in tax, what remained was distributed in roubles. When the authorities found out about the fund, the receiving of the money was blocked. Instead, donations were sent to friends and sympathisers. The [[KGB]] then attempted to halt its distribution by telling the families of political prisoners that, if money were accepted, their loved ones would endure even worse conditions in the camps.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Alexander Ginsburg|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1402107/Alexander-Ginsburg.html|website = Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref>
According to Solzhenitsyn's wife Natalya, the fund counted up to 120 volunteers.<ref name=kifa />
== Post-Soviet Russia == The Aid Fund was revived in the 1990s. It supports impoverished former dissenters.<ref name="walker-altruism" />{{Rp|190}} It also instituted a support program for Russian libraries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ходорович|first1=Сергей|title=Люди Русского фонда|journal=Журнал Неволя|date=2007|volume=13|accessdate=1 December 2015|url=http://index.org.ru/nevol/2007-13/hodorovich_n13.html}}</ref>

'''Stuart B. Schwartz''' is the George Burton Adams Professor of History at [[Yale University]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yale.edu/history/faculty/schwartz.html |title=Stuart B. Schwartz | Department of History | Yale University |publisher=Yale.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429000411/http://www.yale.edu/history/faculty/schwartz.html |archivedate=2012-04-29 |df= }}</ref> the Chair of the Council of Latin American and Iberian Studies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/staff.html |title=Latin American and Iberian Studies |publisher=Yale.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> and the former Master of [[Ezra Stiles College]].<ref name="yaledailynews2002">{{cite web |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2002/may/09/schwartz-named-new-stiles-master |title=Schwartz named new Stiles master |publisher=Yale Daily News |date=2002-05-09 |accessdate=2012-04-04 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Education== Professor Schwartz was born in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]]. As an undergraduate he studied at [[Middlebury College]] and the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico|Universidad Autonoma de Mexico]]. After receiving his undergraduate degree from Middlebury, he went on to study Latin American History at [[Columbia University]] where he received his Ph.D. in 1968.
==Career== After Columbia, Professor Schwartz taught at the [[University of Minnesota]] before joining the Yale faculty in 1996.<ref>http://www.pearsonhighered.com/showcase/stearns6ap/po6.html</ref> Yale President [[Richard Levin]] has referred to Professor Schwartz as, "perhaps the most outstanding scholar of Brazilian history" in the world."<ref name="yaledailynews2002"/> Schwartz has also undertaken scholarly research on Spain, Portugal and their colonies in the early modern Atlantic world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/newsletter_spr10/latinamericascholarship.html |title=The MacMillan Center Newsletter |publisher=Yale.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref>
==Works and awards== His scholarly publications include ''Sovereignty and Society in Colonial Brazil'' (1973), ''Early Latin America'' (1983), ''Sugar Plantations in the Formation of Brazilian Society'' (1985), ''Slaves, Peasants, and Rebels'' (1992), as editor, ''A Governor and His Image in Baroque Brazil'' (1979), ''Implicit Understandings'' (1994), ''Victors and Vanquished: Spanish and Nahua Views of the Conquest of Mexico'' (2000), ''Cambridge History of Peoples of the Americas. South America'' (1999).
In 2008 Schwartz published ''All Can Be Saved: Religious Toleration and Salvation in the Iberian Atlantic World'' (Yale University Press).<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|author=Stuart B. Schwartz |url=http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/book.asp?isbn=9780300125801 |title=All Can Be Saved - Schwartz, Stuart B - Yale University Press |publisher=Yalepress.yale.edu |date=2008-05-12 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> The book traces the idea of tolerance in the Hispanic world from 1500-1820, focusing on the attitudes of common people rather than elites.<ref>For source discussion for ''All Can Be Saved'', see: Schwartz, ''Saved'', Introduction.</ref> The book received numerous awards including the 2008 [[Cundill International Prize]] in History, the 2009 [[American Academy of Religion]] Book Award for Excellence in the category of Historical Study of Religion,<ref>https://www.aarweb.org/programs-services/book-awards</ref> the 2009 John E. Fagg Prize awarded by the [[American Historical Association]],<ref>https://www.historians.org/awards-and-grants/past-recipients/john-e-fagg-prize-recipients</ref> the 2009 George L. Mosse Prize awarded by the American Historical Association,<ref>https://www.historians.org/awards-and-grants/past-recipients/george-l-mosse-prize-recipients</ref> the 2009 [[Leo Gershoy Award]] awarded by the American Historical Association,<ref>https://www.historians.org/awards-and-grants/past-recipients/leo-gershoy-award-recipients</ref> and the Bolton-Johnson Prize awarded by the [[Conference on Latin American History]].<ref name="clah.h-net.org">http://clah.h-net.org/?page_id=174</ref><ref name="autogenerated1"/> Schwartz's first Bolton-Johnson Prize was awarded to his book ''Sugar Plantation in the Formation of Brazilian Society'' (1985).<ref name="clah.h-net.org"/>
Schwartz was a fellow of the [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation]]<ref>https://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/stuart-b-schwartz/</ref> and the [[Institute for Advanced Study|Institute of Advanced Studies]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]].<ref>https://www.ias.edu/scholars/stuart-schwartz</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bedfordstmartins.com/Catalog/Author/stuartbschwartz-1 |title=Bedford/St. Martin's :: Our Authors::Stuart B. Schwartz |publisher=Bedfordstmartins.com |date=2010-01-06 |accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> In 1983 he served as chair of the [[Conference on Latin American History]], the professional organization of Latin American historians.<ref>http://clah.h-net.org/?page_id=542</ref>
Professor Schwartz lives in [[Guilford, Connecticut]] and Puerto Rico with his wife, scholar Maria Jordán, a Senior Lecturer in the Departments of Spanish and Portuguese and a Lecturer in History at Yale, and author of ''Soñar La Historia: Vida y Textos de Lucrecia de León en la España del Siglo de Oro'' (Madrid: Siglo XXI, 2007).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yale.edu/history/faculty/jordan.html |title=Maria Jordan | Department of History | Yale University |publisher=Yale.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-04-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120428235904/http://www.yale.edu/history/faculty/jordan.html# |archive-date=2012-04-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>

'''Swedish Ido Association''' was founded in Stockholm 21 April 1911<ref>Dictionary Nordisk Familjebok, Uggleupplagan vol 27, p. 982. Nordisk Familjeboks Förlag, 1913</ref> and was associated with [[Uniono por la linguo internaciona]] - ULI. The purpose was to promote the usage of the universal [[Ido language]] in Sweden.
During the 1930s the Swedish Ido Association was one of the largest associations in Sweden that advocated the usage of a universal language. The association had about 200 exercising and 100 supporting members.<ref>Periodical Röster i Radio, No 3 March 1933</ref> The association published periodicals and literature in Ido. Among other periodicals Komuniki (1964–1988)<ref>[http://libris.kb.se/bib/663285 Swedish Royal Library Libris]</ref> Svensk Världsspråkstidning 1925-59<ref>[http://libris.kb.se/bib/9174467 Swedish Royal Library Libris]</ref> and Mondo 1912-34<ref>[http://libris.kb.se/bib/9175054 Swedish Royal Library Libris]</ref> can be mentioned.
Due to receding numbers of members, an extra general meeting decided to dissolve the association in Stockholm 2 August 1996. At this meeting the [[Ido-foundation for Language Research in Memory of Hellmut Röhnisch]]<ref>[http://www.idofonduro.org The website of the Ido-foundation for Language Research in Memory of Hellmut Röhnisch]</ref> was created using the assets of the association. [[Hellmut Röhnisch]] was the last chairman of the Swedish Ido Association.

The '''Ukrainian oligarchs''' are a group of [[business oligarchs]] that quickly appeared on the economic and political scene of [[Ukraine]] after its independence in 1991, just as happened in neighboring [[Post-Soviet states|post-Soviet state]] [[Russia]].Virtual Politics - Faking Democracy in the Post-Soviet World, [[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Andrew Wilson]], [[Yale University Press]], 2005, {{ISBN|0-300-09545-7}}[http://www.rferl.org/content/Ukraines_New_Rulers_What_Do_They_Want/2061377.html Ukraine's New Rulers: What Do They Want?], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (June 03, 2010) In 2008, the combined wealth of Ukraine's 50 richest oligarchs was equal to 85% of Ukraine's GDP.{{cite journal|last=Kuzio|first=Taras|title=OLIGARCHS WIELD POWER IN UKRAINIAN POLITICS|journal=Eurasia Daily Monitor|date=1 July 2008|volume=5|issue=125|url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=33765}} In November 2013 this number was 45% (of GDP).http://www.ecfr.eu/page/-/ECFR_160_SURVIVAL_OF_THE_RICHEST-_HOW_OLIGARC1_BLOCK_REFORM_IN_UKRAINE.pdf By 2015, due to the [[Ukrainian crisis]], the total net worth of the five richest and most influential Ukrainians ([[Rinat Akhmetov]], [[Viktor Pinchuk]], [[Ihor Kolomoyskyi]], [[Henadiy Boholyubov]] and [[Yuriy Kosiuk]]) had dropped from $21.6 billion in 2014 to $11.85 billion in June 2015.{{cite web|url=http://carnegieendowment.org/2016/02/03/decisive-turn-risks-for-ukrainian-democracy-after-euromaidan-pub-62641 |title=A Decisive Turn? Risks for Ukrainian Democracy After the Euromaidan |publisher=[[Carnegie Endowment for International Peace]] |date=February 3, 2016 |accessdate=}} (In 2014 Ukrainian GDP fell by 7%; in 2015 it shrunk 12%.https://www.economist.com/blogs/freeexchange/2016/01/lviv-not-donetsk) ==Usage== Oligarchs are usually defined as businessmen having direct influence on both [[Politics of Ukraine|politics]] and economy. During the 1990s, the oligarchs emerged as well-connected [[Nouveau riche|entrepreneurs who started from nearly nothing and got rich]] through participation in the market via connections to the corrupt, but democratically elected government of Ukraine during the state's transition to a [[market economy|market-based economy]]. Later numerous Ukrainian businesspeople have "taken over control" of political parties (examples of this are [[Party of Greens of Ukraine]], [[Labour Ukraine]] and [[Social Democratic Party of Ukraine (united)]]) or started new ones to gain seats and influence in the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament). The rise of the oligarchs has been connected to the processes of [[privatization]] of state-owned assets. These processes usually involved the distribution of [[property title]]s of such enterprises, land, and real estate, on equal base to the whole population of the country, through instruments such as [[privatization voucher]]s, certificates, and coupons. Given the different preferences of people in relation to risk-aversity, property titles were easily re-sold. Businessmen who could provide an initial investment capital to collect such property titles could thus easily arrive to the property of whole former public holdings. The oligarchs' influence on the [[Government of Ukraine|Ukrainian Government]] is extreme. In 2011 some analysts and Ukrainian politicians believed that some Ukrainian businesses tycoons, with "lucrative relations" with [[Russia]], were deliberately hindering [[Ukraine–European Union relations|Ukraine's European Union integration]].[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/119066/ EU Hopes Fade As Gas Lobby Triumphs], [[Kyiv Post]] (16 December 2011) ==Most influential== In January 2001 only two people of this list were seen as being an oligarch by the general public (Lazarenko and Tymoshenko, topping a [[Kyiv International Institute of Sociology]] survey in January 2001).[https://books.google.com/books?id=Rr3aAAAAQBAJ&pg=RA1-PT29&dq=Pavlo+Lazarenko+Fatherland+faction&hl=nl&sa=X&ei=GQBoUv_nHIPUtAaOhYC4AQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Pavlo%20Lazarenko%20Fatherland%20faction&f=false Democratic Revolution in Ukraine: From Kuchmagate to Orange Revolution] by [[Taras Kuzio]], [[Routledge]], 2009, {{ISBN|0415441412}} (chapter 4){{synthesis-inline|date=May 2017}} *[[Rinat Akhmetov]] is the wealthiest man in [[Ukraine]]. *[[Petro Poroshenko]], the fifth and current [[President of Ukraine]]. *[[Viktor Yanukovych]], the fourth [[President of Ukraine]] *[[Leonid Chernovetskyi]], one of the first bankers in Ukraine, former [[Mayor of Kyiv|mayor]] of the capital [[Kyiv]]. *[[Dmytro Firtash]], the most important figure in the vital [[natural gas|gas industry]]. *[[Ihor Kolomoyskyi]], the second/third richest person in Ukraine since at least 2006.{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21647355-building-nation-means-putting-plutocrats-their-place-president-v-oligarch |title=President v oligarch |newspaper=The Economist |date=28 March 2015 |accessdate=28 March 2015}} *[[Viktor Pinchuk]], the son-in-law of ex-president [[Leonid Kuchma]] who controls much of the nation's media. *[[Yulia Tymoshenko]], former [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]], speculated to be one of the wealthiest persons in Ukraine (although she claims to have a modest income).[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/nov/26/ukraine.gender The millionaire revolutionary], [[The Guardian]] (November 26, 2004)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/70065/ While leading lavish lifestyles, politicians declare almost pauper-like incomes, assets] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623011139/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/70065/ |date=2010-06-23 }}, [[Kyiv Post]] (June 17, 2010){{uk icon}} '''Vernon Lee Evans''' is a [[contract killer]] convicted for murdering two witnesses scheduled to testify against the leader of a drug gang. In 1984, he was convicted and sentenced to death together with [[drug lord|drug kingpin]] [[Anthony Grandison]] for the 1983 murders of Susan Kennedy and David Scott Piechowicz. David Piechowicz and his wife Cheryl (Susan Kennedy's sister) had been scheduled to testify against Grandison at trial on federal drug charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indybay.org/news/2006/02/1800526.php|title=DP Victory in Maryland - Vernon Evans Wins Stay of Execution!|publisher=The AP|date=|accessdate=2006-02-06}}</ref>
The case was intensely discussed in the political debate about eliminating the death penalty in Maryland.<ref name="WagnerIssue">{{cite news|last1=Wagner|first1=John|title=5 inmates on death row are at issue|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/1324365374/fulltext/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/88?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=Washington Post|date=8 April 2013}}</ref>
==Conviction and sentencing==
Evans' death sentence was overturned on appeal in 1991. The following year, a new jury again sentenced him to die.<ref name="LevineDate">{{cite news|last1=Levine|first1=Susan|title=A Shorter Line on Death Row; Pr. George's Man May Be Months From Execution Date|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/409627652/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/84?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=Washingotn Post|date=19 June 2004}}</ref> In 1994, the new sentence was upheld on direct appeal to the [[Maryland Court of Appeals]], and in 1997 a petition for post-conviction relief was denied. The U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland denied Evans' federal habeas corpus petition in 1999, and in 2000 that decision was upheld by the Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit. Since then, Evans has filed motions for a new trial and to correct an illegal sentence. Those, however, have been denied as well. He was scheduled for execution in February 2006, but his execution was suspended. All executions in Maryland are currently on hold until the state drafts and approves new execution procedures.
The status of Evens' death sentence became unclear along with that of four other convicted murderers when the [[Maryland House of Delegates]] voted in 2013 to abolish the death penalty.<ref name="GuardianLimbo">{{cite news|title=End of death penalty leaves five in limbo|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/1319797560/fulltext/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/59?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=The Guardian|date=22 March 2013}}</ref> On December 31, 2014, Evans' death sentence was one of four commuted to life without parole by outgoing governor [[Martin O'Malley]]<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/maryland-gov-martin-omalley-commutes-four-death-sentences-n277551 ''Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley Commutes Four Death Sentences'']</ref><ref name="BradnerSentences">{{cite news |last1=Bradner |first1=Eric |title=O'Malley commutes Maryland's last four death sentences |url=https://www.cnn.com/2014/12/31/politics/omalley-commutes-marylands-last-four-death-sentences/index.html |accessdate=14 June 2018 |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=31 Cecember 2014}}</ref><ref name="BlinderMaryland">{{cite news |last1=Blinder |first1=Alan |title=Life Sentences for Last Four Facing Death in Maryland |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/01/us/maryland-governor-omalley-commutes-death-sentences-emptying-death-row.html |accessdate=14 June 2018 |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=31 December 2014}}</ref>
==Anti death penalty activism== Concern that anti death penalty activists would protest Evans execution violently, Maryland State Police carried out undercover surveillance of anti death penalty activists for fourteen months. The operation was ended when it came to light; Governor [[Martin O'Malley]] called it an "infring(ment) on citizens' rights to free speech or public assembly."<ref name="ReinJudgement">{{cite news|last1=Rein|first1=Lisa|title=Anticipated Death Penalty Protests Prompted Spying; Md. Police Chief Says Surveillance Showed Poor Judgment|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/410227954/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/39?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=Washington Post|date=26 July 2008}}</ref><ref name="DechterReport">{{cite news|last1=Dechter|first1=Gadi|title=SURVEILLANCE WAS 'MISGUIDED': STATE POLICE SUPERINTENDENT TO ADOPT ALL RECOMMENDATIONS IN 93-PAGE REPORT|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/406212753/fulltext/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/108?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=Baltimore Sun|date=2 October 2008}}</ref>
While on death row, anti death penalty activists enabled Evans to write an advice blog designed, according to the [[Chicago Tribune]] as "the leading edge of a strategy by death penalty opponents to use new technologies" by making the public see criminals sentenced to death as "human beings with lives beyond the crimes they are accused of."<ref name="RichAdvice">{{cite news|last1=Rich|first1=Eric|title=Via blog, man on Death Row gives advice|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/420420620/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/12?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=29 January 2006}}</ref><ref name="McMenaminLife">{{cite news|last1=McMenamin|first1=Jennifer|title=Answers sent from death row ; Evans' blog gives a glimpse of his life|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/406673143/821877B5049E45FCPQ/1?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=Baltimore Sun|date=27 January 2006}}</ref><ref name="BorgerMan">{{cite news|last1=Borger|first1=Julian|title=Death row blogger describes last days of condemned man|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/246395804/821877B5049E45FCPQ/3?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2006}}</ref><ref name="LastDays">{{cite news|title=Deathrow inmate blogs in last days|url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/467783295/fulltext/FB02A45CACA847D7PQ/62?accountid=10226|accessdate=29 May 2018|publisher=UPI|date=27 January 2006}}</ref><ref name="JohnsonSpirituality">{{cite book|last1=Johnson|first1=Andre|title=Urban God Talk: Constructing a Hip Hop Spirituality|date=2013|publisher=Lexington Books|isbn=0739168304|page=98}}</ref> In his blog, Evans claimed not to have committed the murder.<ref name="RichAdvice"/>

Bhutto Government]] | committees = | portfolio = | religion =[[Islam]] | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | blank1 = | data1 = | blank2 = | data2 = | blank3 = | data3 = | blank4 = | data4 = | blank5 = | data5 = | nickname = | allegiance = | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | unit = | commands = | battles = | awards = | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = }} '''Muhamad Yusuf Khan Khattak''' ([[Urdu]]:محمد یوسف خان خٹک; b. 18 November 1917 – 29 July 1991) best known as '''Yusuf Khattak''', was a Pakistani politician, [[Socialism in Pakistan|left-wing]] intellectual, lawyer, and noted [[Pakistan Movement]] [[:Category:Pakistan Movement activists|activist]] from Khyber Pakhtunkwa. Although an early member of the [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]], he actively participated in politics through the [[Socialism in Pakistan|left-oriented]] [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP), which he served as the [[Cabinet of Pakistan|minister of petroleum]] under the government of Prime Minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]]. He was a highly respectable elder [[Politician|statesman]] and represented Pakistan at various international conferences throughout his long statesmanship. ==Biography== ===Early life and education=== Khattak was born into a prominent [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]] ''[[Khattak]]'' family, in [[Kohat]], [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–1955)|North-West Frontier Province]] now Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province.{{cite web|last=Govt. Pakistan|title=Mohammad Yousaf Khan Khattak|url=http://www.pakpost.gov.pk/philately/stamps2003/mohammad_yousaf_khan_khattak.html|work=Government of Pakistan, August 14, 2003|publisher=Pakistan Post Office|accessdate=23 December 2013}} His father, Khan Bahadur Kuli Khan Khattak, was an influential figure in the nationalist politics of the then-[[North-West Frontier Province (1901–55)|North-West Frontier Province]]. His younger brother, [[Aslam Khattak]] also served as the [[Governor of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], and [[Habibullah Khan Khattak|Habibullah Khattak]] later enjoyed a distinguish career with the [[Pakistan Army]]. After initially studying at the private [[Aitchison College]] in [[Lahore]], he made a [[College transfer|transfer]] to the renowned [[Government College University, Lahore|Government College University]] (GCU) in Lahore. At [[Government College University, Lahore|GCU]], he graduated with BA in [[comparative literature]] and poetry, and moved to the United Kingdom for higher studies. He attended the [[Oxford University]] where he earned a BA in history, followed by MA in [[modern history]]. At [[Oxford University]], he passed the [[Bar examination|bar exam]] to practice law and was [[Lincoln's Inn]]. However, he returned to [[India]] to join the [[All India Muslim League|Muslim League]] and played a prominent role in the [[Pakistan Movement]]. ===Political activism and the petroleum ministry=== In November 1946, he led a group of 100 volunteers of Frontier Muslim League to Bihar for relief work after the massacre of Muslims there. During this time, Khattak was arrested and sent to jail along with other leaders of the Muslim League. ln spite of his release orders, he refused to come out of the jail and persistently defied the orders by remaining behind the bars till [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] gave clarion call to the Muslim League leaders to fight the battle for referendum in North West Frontier Province. Yusuf Khattak led the [[Pakistan Movement]] section against the Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa [[Indian Congress|Congress government]] under [[Dr Khan Sahib]]. A close confidante of [[Liaqat Ali Khan]], he became secretary general of the [[Muslim League (Pakistan)|Muslim League]] after the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947. However, he fell out with Muslim League Chief Minister Abdul Qayyum Khan, who actively organised a campaign to oust him and his colleagues like [[Barrister Khan Saifullah Khan]], from any role in provincial politics. He was then elected secretary general of the Provincial Muslim League, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa in 1949. He was soon elevated to the prominent position of secretary general of All Pakistan Muslim League the same year thereby succeeding Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan as secretary general of the league. Frequently in the opposition, he was elected the leader of the opposition in the National Assembly and was a prominent leader in the campaign of [[Fatima Jinnah]] against Field Marshal [[Ayub Khan (Field Marshal)|Ayub Khan]]'s military government. A prominent critic of [[Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan]]s [[Pakhtunistan]] policy, he also rejected the [[National Awami Party]]'s claim to be the sole representative of [[Pashtuns]]. Reconciling with Qayyum Khan before the bye elections 1971 election, he joined the Pakistan Muslim League-Qayyum faction and contested and won the election from Qayyum Khan's vacated [[Peshawar]] seat. As part of Qayyum Khan's alliance with the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]], Yusuf Khattak was appointed Federal Minister for Fuel, Power and Natural Resources in Prime Minister [[Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto]]'s Cabinet. He was re-elected to his seat in the 1977 election despite the Qayyum League's rout. In 1990 the [[Government of Pakistan]] gave him a gold medal for his services to Pakistan.[http://www.pakpost.gov.pk/philately/stamps2003/mohammad_yousaf_khan_khattak.html Pakistan Post Office Commerotive stamps] == See also == *[[Aslam Khattak]] *[[Abdul Qayyum Khan]] *[[Liaqat Ali Khan]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://zeejah.tripod.com/dad.html Muhammad Yusuf Khan Khattak ...A Daughter's Tribute] by Zeenath Jehan *[http://www.pakpost.gov.pk/philately/stamps2003/mohammad_yousaf_khan_khattak.html PakPost] {{Pakistan Movement}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khattak, Muhammad Yusuf Khan}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:Pakistan Peoples Party politicians]] [[Category:Government College University, Lahore alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Pakistani scholars]] [[Category:Pakistani activists]] [[Category:Pakistan Movement activists from the North-West Frontier Province]] [[Category:Aitchison College alumni]] [[Category:Khattak family]]
